A long way to the top, but worth it!. Very impressive, we went on an incredibly hot day, but there is lots to see and do here, and the views are pretty breathtaking.The heat generated by the golden mount in the sun is pretty intense!
Lovely!!. Really impressive place, specially when you see the three buildings together. Walking around the area is very nice and the continuous restoring of the place is impressive.

Stunning view of BKK. Nice temple on artificial mountain in the old town of Bangkok, with a great view over the city. We took the klong boat to go there very easy and it's the last stop. Be careful a man came to us and said the temple is close and want to take us in his tuktuk to the big Buddha this is a scam don't fall for it.
Stairway to golden mountain and nice views. It's stairway to temple on mountain. Right around boat station. Temple is nice, good views on Bangkok. Not too expensive, but not free.
It now charges $20 Baht. Still well worth the gentle stair climb. Many shrines and misting waterfalls on the way up. A very peaceful experience. Beautiful 360 views of the city.

Temple with a difference.. This lesser known tourist attraction is a jewel. A gentle helter-skelter climb to the top gives excellent views of the city whilst the temple holds true to Buddhism in its architecture and artifacts. The sculptured animals of the Chinese calendar intrigue.

Great views, do not forget to visit the ancient scriptures. For budist people is a very important temple.
The main beauty of the temple is the builing, its location, and the views. It is also a very nice experience to see how important and sacred is for Thai people.
Do not forget to visit the ancient text (XX centuries old) in the base of the mountain.

Important site to visit in Bangkok. An excellent cultural site in Bangkok to visit during any tour around the city. Culture, religious, historical. Like all such sites in Thailand the amount of information on its history, origins etc is extremely limited so you have to research yourself first. One of the highest points in Bangkok old Rattanakosin area.

good view. it might not be a must view but in the end you get a nice view over Bangkok for cheap Money and you can do it without too much time. i would recommend to do it.
you can hammer the big bell for fun as well ;)

Great place to visit. If you are thinking about taking a trip to Bangkok and you want to visit a beautiful place that is more secluded, this is the spot to go. This was a very relaxing experience for us, and the view we saw at the top was truly amazing. The Golden Mount (Wat Saket) is actually a temple, so the atmosphere here is very calm and peaceful, making you connect to your spiritual side. There are many stairs to climb to get to the top, but it will definitely be worth the effort. I personally really enjoyed this visit, and I would definitely recommend it.

Temple with Commanding View. While there are more famous temples in Bangkok, The Golden Mount temple was my favorite for the spectacular 360 degree view of Bangkok from the very top.There is no fee for entry and there is quite a climb to get to the very top...but it is worth particularly of you time your visit to the late afternoon when the light offers some excellent photo opportunities.

Much better than Wat Arun. Not a mountain, but you do get good views, and it is much easier to access than Wat Arun which has very steep steps. Wat Saket, is a nice gentle Incline that all but the most elderly can climb. It is nice temple with the bells to ring which i think all the children enjoy. When i visited there was building work happening which ruined some of the views...

Not very impressive. Not a big deal, just another temple like the others. Just walking on top makes it different. There is no any side view of bangkok same as the other high places view. Its realy strange after reading other reviews. We could not find the things which are writtin in reviews in here.

Interesting place with a good view.. We had a quick stop at this place for our first look at a temple in Thailand. It is worth the climb to the temple at the top. Has an interesting view of Bangkok on the roof.

A nice place to visit. Away from all the other busy tourist areas, you will see some tourists who have ventured away from the usual tourist areas, but its not crowded with people. It is relaxing and has a great view up the top. Worth making the effort to get to.
Great view. It's well worth going up the stairs so you can enjoy a nice view of the city from the top of the mount.
Wat Saket. Great 360 degrees view at the very top. It's a climb involving lots of stairs but worth it when you see the view.

A peak for view. Wat Saket is another Budhist temple. The special thing about it is its location. Just across the Democracy monument opposite Kaosan Rd. on top of high hill. You climb the stairs to get to see a panoramic view of Ko Rattanakosin (the old city). On clear day you can see the Grand palace, Chaopraya river and China town.

Good view, maybe not a must see. Good climb up the man made mountain with an excellent view of the city. However, there are many other Wats in Bangkok that should rank higher on the priority list to see. Maybe starting with the Grand Palace did not help us in managing expectations.
Climb to the top for a good view of Bangkok. It was well worth the climb to see the Golden Mount , 360 degree view of Bangkok and ring the bells and gongs.

It's all about the view. In my opinion, there are many better temples in Bangkok than this but you can't climb to the top of those and you can this. It's a cheap "should do" rather than a "must do". The steps are not that difficult and there are stop off respites along the way, so it's not too arduous a trip. The views from the top are what makes this effort worthwhile
A view over Bangkok. Walk to Wat Saket and take the stairs to the top and get a beuatyfull view over Bangkok. There also is a small temple on the way up, that you can visit

worth the walk. For 20 baht this was my favourite morning spent in Bangkok. The climb to the top is long but it is woth it for the view of the city from the top. The golden buddha and other religious statues inside are beautiful. Don't miss the large Buddha statue on the side path on the way down.

See Bangkok from the top. If you would like to see bangkok from a mountain top this is the place to be. For only 20baht, climb up the stairs going to the bells and big dong - (do not forget to make a wish :)). After climbing less than a 100 steps you will see a lot of monk in the temple and a smaller replica of the reclining budha. Should i recommend this? - if you have enough time try to visit it but you can forego it if you have limited time.

Very impressive. During a mad day tour of the city, we threw ourselves around the Golden Mountain. I never feel completely comfortable in a place of worship when I am not a believer. However it was a hugely impressive creation and the greatness of the golden bell at the top is a sight to be seen. There is currently work being done in and around the Mount so if travelling now expect to see a bit of scaffolding etc. It is a bit out the way as well and the taxis and tuttuts around will try and trap you into paying more and or taking you on 'one stop' (this is basically taking you to a shop you don't want to go to for them to get commission). So I advise you get a taxi or a tuttut to wait for you. This is easy, just organise this at the point of pickup and should not cost you any more than 100baht.

Nice place and many steeps to walk.... If you like to go to a place with a nice wiev of BKK and dont mind to walk up many steeps the you should go to Golden Mountain. I brought my 10 years old son to this place and he also liked it, maybe because al the bells he could "beeling" on. I dont think they like if you use the beels to much but some you for sure can do if its not to loud... And when you are on the top you will get a amazing view of BKK. So this is really a must when you come to BKK

great view. There are 380 stairs to the top. This is a very beautiful Wat on an mountain.In addition, Wat Saket’s living history, peaceful atmosphere and panoramic views of Bangkok have made it one of my favorite spots I've been in Bkk.The walk way to the top was perfect. The temple was very nice and clean. The entrance fee is 20 baht, it's really cheap for an fantastic experienceWould totally recommend.
Kitsch but fun climb. A fun thing to do. Ignore the tacky souvenir shop and head for the rooftop for the views of the city.
Good, but alot of climbing. everyone sees it. so you have to really, but I am scared of heights, so it was challenging! But worth the climb.

high above bangkok. 120 odd steps up but it is beautiful the walk up has such atmosphere, a smoke machine, waterfall, beautiful statues. and the top has too, lots of offerings and salutes to buddha, would have been better long ago though if the skyline hadnt been over run with skyscrapes unfortunately

I like it!. Great place! In the 15-20-minute walk from Khaosan Road. The rise of the hill is very picturesque and not tedious because have many recreations with benches.The rise may be suitable for middle-aged people.Do not forget when lifting and descending the stairs to call all the bells, in order to fulfill all your desires)))There is awesome view of the city at the top of the hill. You can buy souvenirs here.There is pier from which you can reach by boat to Protunam market and major shopping centers in just 12 baht not far from the Golden mount, after the bridge over the canal.

Amazing place!. We loved our visit to the Golden Mount. It's so beautiful! The walk up the numerous steps is fun with the bells you get to ring along the way which is part of a ritual. Once on top, you have an amazing view of Bangkok. It was part of a Tuktuk tour we had with Intrepid. Would definitely recommend it!

Amazaing!. I have spent here some of the most relaxing afternoon hours in my life with a soft rain dripping on my head as I walked up the stairs of the Golden Mount. Hiding from the shower in one of the temples was meditation pure.
Good, if you have not much else to do. A decent little attraction, with a nice climb and some good views, but there is precious little here to keep you interested once you get past the way it looks.
Not a must. It is an important temple but not very impressive to the tourist. You climb to the top you get a view of suburban Bangkok, also not a must
Great view for the top. Be ready to climb steps but it is all worth the climb. Nice temple and beautiful view if wat po, wat arun and the palace.

lovely place. A very nice place to visit. You go up the steps to the top and there is a nice view of Bangkok. the children really enjoyed the bells that you can ring along the way. Also when you come back down they provide free drinks and food! it was a noodle and chicken soup which was really nice. Its a place to visit if you just have that little extra time..only need an hour or so here.

Awsome view, nice temple. Amazinng view over Bangkok, quiet location. Nice temple where you can feel the atmosphere of a real buddhist temple. Nice walk to climb to the top of the hill, and the view worth it.Amust see, and one of the peaceful points you will be surprised to find in such a busy city as Bangkok.

lovely view!. This is just a 3-minute walk from Phanfa Pier (so if you're coming from Pratunam area, just ride the khlong boats, get off at Phanfa Pier and walk towards this temple) and about 7-10 minute walk from Democracy Monument. Yes, there will be a lot of climbing going to the temple but dont worry because it's not as tiring as you expect it to be. Be fascinated with the lovely view of the city as you go up.
Good view. Go up the golden mount, and view the surrounding area where there are plenty of heritage sites.Those who love to walk and look at heritage sites, this can be a beacon

Cool view. The golden mount offers the visitors what all the other temples offer and that is Buddha. Many Buddhas to appreciate. On the top of the temple, one needs to climb a narrow staircase and, once you arrive on top, you are delighted by the amazing view over Bangkok. It is common to find people and monks praying around the Golden Mount. Nice indeed!
The best place. I love this place. Good place. Good menu. Good service. I'll come back to you again, the Golden Mount.

Nice and cheap activity. For only 20 bath you can clime this mountain, look over BKK and breathe in some fresh air. At the start you have a guy giving you a free bracelet and a blessing which was quite funny (love, love, love for you, luck, luck, luck for you, money, money money for you etc.). After that the 15 minutes climb to the top starts. On your way you can sound the bells which is supposed to give you good luck. At the top you have a nice view. There were also Thai people praying and you can buy yourself a drink. Enjoy!

Mountain in Bangkok.... Certainly not a mountain by any means but for Bangkok, a rather big hill. It is a decent hike to the top but well worth the effort. The city views from the top are better than any hill could produce..unobstructed for 360º. The mount is well landscaped and if you poke around and follow small trails, you may find old markers from past donors and honoured families. I found a German man's marker from another time...but watch for snakes. I saw the end of one and am happy he (or she, for that matter) didn't care to have a look at me. There is a small restaurant/coffee shop on the way up but NOT accessible on the way down so grab your snack or caffeine on the way up.

Worthwhile. We didn't want to join the crowds and do the Palace tour so we came here instead. Very enjoyable visit but lots of steps to climb - although there is space to catch your breath on the way up.
Great views. The Golden mount was one of my favourite attractions in Bangkok. It's cheap to climb and not to strenuous to climb. Views from the top are great and lots to look at as you climb. GREAT!

Worth a visit. It was a cheap place to visit (only 20 Baht) with a short but entertaining walk with the temple bells and gong to keep you busy. The views from the top are amazing and really worth the walk.

Beautiful!. Very beautiful Wat on an mountain, which provides you with nice views over Bangkok ( and the possibility to catch some winds!) Easy walk up and greatly rewarded. Buy some Temple bells, nice souvenir back home!

Bangkok view. If you would like to see view around Bangkok you should come here. For thai people its free but tourist must pray for donation. This is very old temple and special. On the top of mountain you can see the view of Bangkok and go to pray bone of monk from india. Its stay here so long time a go. U you can go here by bus from siam number 15,47 pass this temple or from small canal boat in the end of way.
Good view. Watching Bangkok from the highest Budha temple in town, is really worth to step-up untill the top. I prefer visiting in the morning, before it's too hot and too many people come.
Breathing Space. For 20 baht you get a lovely 360 view of the city and it feels a world away from the chaos below! Worth a visit and loads of gongs to sound on the way for the kids.

Very Inspiring!. Take your time climbing the spiral staircase, meditate on top, ring the bells, hit the gongs, see golden dome reflecting sunlight. I had to cancel my following visit to walk around the place for an extra hour. Very Inspiring!
Awesome. Amazing view of the city especially with the oncoming storm clouds which made for great pics. We were lucky enough to witness the visit of around 60 monks praying and chanting
Sight of the city. Kinda' weird and kisch temple with status all the way up, some bells and in the topa good sight of the city. But there isn't anything important to see.
Great view. Avoid midday it was busy and hot! It's a fair climb but worth it. It was 20 baht to go up definitely worth 40p!!I would do it again.

Superb Place to Visit. If you visiting this spot you can enjoy a breathtaking view of Bangkok that will definitely impress you. I personally think that the view here is the best you can find in this city. Besides the view, this place itself is great. It is a museum on the top of a mountain, which is very beautiful, giving you an amazing feeling of calm and serenity. It is a little challenging to get here, giving you quite a workout, but trust me when I say it`s worth it. It is my honest opinion that if you are in Bangkok, you must go and see this place.

What a view!. So we somehow just managed to stumble on this place, so glad we did. It was 20 baht to get in so we figured why not? It says it is 120 steps to the top but they are very shallow and it did not feel like much of a climb at all as they have lots of landings between sets of stairs that have very ornate bells and gongs alongside statues hidden in the trees. Be sure to look in every nook and cranny you will undoubtable find something to take pictures of. When you reach the top there is a hall with Buddha images and a place to give offerings and then it is up the narrow staircase to the open roof. The views from here are spectacular and 360 degrees so you can like us try and figure out in which direction you live. The contrast of old and new Bangkok is startling and you could spend a fair amount of time up here just watching the world go by. Defiantly worth it, go on, you know you want to!

Great view. A steady climb up shallow steps, made easier because we could stop along the way to ring the bells and take photos. There was a coffee shop and toilet stop half-way up, so on a hotter day than we had, you could take a longer break if necessary. Fantastic 360 degree view from the top. A fun way to get here is to take the water taxi along Khlong Saen Saep. We visited Jim Thompson's House first, then headed towards the canal. Turn right and walk along the canal to the water taxi stop. Be prepared to leap on as the boat whizzes up to the pier. Scramble into your seat, pay the conductor a few bahts and enjoy your mad, high-speed dash along the khlong. Stay on the boat until it stops at the Phan Fa pier. You'll see the Golden Mount from there.
A hot but worth lil climb. This attraction is a climb up staggered steps that assend to an eventual great view of Bangkok. Well worth a visit. There are some good picture opportunities along the way.

interesting. downside was we were talked into taking a tuk tuk there from a street guy and only got there after having to take detour to jewellery and fashion house ,despite our protests , as driver said he earns money if we go there , eventually paid him not to go to any more , just gave hime what he supposedly earns from these detours, message of the story - only take a tuk tuk to where YOU want to go !!!
lovely!. i have been to bangkok a few times and never been to this temple. that's a big mistake. its a lovely place and a fantastic setting - it's my new favourite!

Brilliant view. The walk up the spiral stairs were amazing in itself. But the 360 degree view from the top was spectacular. And while outside, the monks chanting through the speakers, exported me to my happy place within.

Great View. Golden Mount is worth the climb to the top for the great view of the city. There is nothing impressive temple-wise at the top but you are rewarded with a great view of the city. If you like big bells, this is also the place for you as there are hundreds along the walk up and back down. My son loves this place to ring the big bells.

Nice view with a history lesson. For 20 baht, it was a good experience to walk up the path for a view. Personally, the best part was actually at the base of the Mount, where there is a display about famous Buddhist caves and carvings, which was the best part for me. Now I have a list of other places I would like to visit.
Nice. Cheap, nice route up to the golden mountain, a bit to commercial...We had a massive storm coming over so we spend a few hours up there, good shelter.

Worth the climb. There are 380 stairs to the top. Once you reach the top their is a strong breeze and an amazing panoramic of the city and its tall apartments. Its hard to imagine what the city would have looked like when the temple was built.The temple is still in use as a place of worship and this adds to the feel whilst there. The staff are relaxed and you can take your time and roam around.Great to get away from the beers and MSG for a while.
wonderful place. Temple is attractive worth seeing only temple and sleeping buddha to see then every other temple is repetition.

Well worth the visit. Took a 60 baht tuktuk to Golden Mount (later realized it was a tourist tuktuk which makes many stops at tailer and jewelry shops). Not a lot of people at the Wat; entrance was free. Walked up the stairs to the top (nice breeze at the top); ring the bells.
top of Bangkok. When on top of this temple, you can see the whole Bangkok. There are aslo other temples nearby as well.
Great View. I liked the view of this site plus the fact that there is no fee to enjoy it. There is a relaxing/calming effect to being there.

Good Time Killer. If you have time to spare in Bangkok, then a visit to the Golden Mount is nice - but don't make it a priority. The grounds are beautiful, and when you reach the top you get an excellent view of the city. There's not a lot to see at the top, but there are several gongs to ring along the way which was so much fun!

A (daylight only) view on the cheap. For 20Baht, you're getting a bit of respite from the noise and the grind of the city. Ascending the Golden Mount at times felt I was in botanical garden or biosphere with the verdant green-scape that follows the steps and path to temple in the beginning. The view from the top is quite nice though of course the height is much lower than the collection if skyscraper/hotel rooftop bars in town. Still, nice views of city are there for you and the atmosphere is unrushed. Plus the roof of the temple is very wide open so there is plenty of space to roam. THere are also gongs to bang on too...Who can say no to that kind of stress reliever really?
Excellent. Coming from Holland where they arent many temples it was my first temple I went to and It was something that will stay in my memeory for a long time

A fun climb and a super view.. Costs 20 Baht per person and is well worth it. A nice walk up to the top...... the steps are small and easy to deal with. The top has a super view and photo opportunities.

bangkok from one of highest point. to avoid very hot temperatures , best visit early in the morning or at noon around 4 pm ( but don't be too late it closed around 5 pm).you have to climb many stairs., but don't worry you can stop , take a breath, whenever you want, and enjoy the view. Along the stairs there are many bells small and big. Ring it and enjoy.once you reach highest point, you can view bangkok skyline, beautiful. The Wat itself have a gold stupa, that why it called golden mount. IIts worthed to climb, no regret.
Nice to gain height!. If you are sick to visit temples, this one is so high that you enjoy the giant view at least. 20Baht, worth a jump!

what can i say!. This is a nice temple, the fee for the entry is around 20 bht. You need to cross a lot of stairs to be on the top! In the top of the golden mountain you can see the roof of bangkok with a big gold pagoda behind you! nice!
Nice calm and good bangkok view..... Its a nice calm place where you can sit and relax. Great view of Bangkok city but again charges only for Non-thai people... overall worth visiting...

Bird's eye view. Actually one of our highlights in Bangkok - the Golden Mount. 20 Bhaat per person and a few steps later you find yourself on top of the hill and inside a small but decent temple. The highlight, though, is not the temple itself but the views from the top - 360 degrees all over Bangkok. Recommendable.

Nice views with easy walk to the top!. We went to the Golden Mount at Wat Saket in the morning (8 AM). The hours were 7:30 AM to 5:30 PM. The weather was cool in the morning. After we walked up the indoor Buddha level, we went to the top on small stairs. Then we were at the top of the Golden Mount. The views were nice from the top. The walk way to the top was perfect. The temple was very nice and clean. The parking at the temple was adequate. The bathrooms were clean. Recommended.

Wonderful views over all of Bangkok. We really enjoyed visiting the Golden Mount while in Banglamphu. The walk up to the top is very pleasant and not difficult, and the views from the top over the whole city are extraordinary. The structure itself was beautiful too. Would definitely recommend.

Worthwhile. This offers an amazing view of the city. The golden spire on top is very beautiful. Inside there were Buddhist shrines as well as a shop where you could get ice cream. Entry was only 20 b and it was well worth going!

Among the Best of the Second-Tier attractions in Bangkok. The Golden Mount is the most striking feature of the otherwise mundane Wat Saket. Still, it is best experienced as part of a visit to the Wat itself, so that the Wat’s history will strike you and so that the contrast between ordinary Wat and amazing Mount will strike you too. To do this to full effect, enter from Worachat Road, the street on the East side of the Wat. There, a few steps from the sidewalk, a small stone sign, dwarfed by adjacent vegetation, offers in Thai: “Welcome to Wat Saket Ratcha Wora Maha Wihan.” The sign is decidedly unassuming, as is the entirety of Wat Saket. Even with its marble façade, the straight lines of the buildings and lack of unique features seem poised only to emphasize the majesty of the huge Golden Mount, to the north of the grounds. Together, the Wat and the Mount have a macabre, even Kharmic history that lend them enough supernatural weight that educated locals speak its short form rapidly, as if to avoid drawing attention to the name. More superstitious Bangkokians used a barely-whispered, “Saket”. From its founding in 1765, it was as sleepy as its current architecture depicts. All that changed when the Chinese brought Black Plague to all of Asia’s port cities, including Bangkok, between 1790 and 1794. Since by Royal edict, cremations could not take place within the city walls, Saket’s location immediately outside the walls of Rattanakosin Island, and its commodious crematorium made it a natural as the center for the cremation of plague victims. Historians claim the smoke from Saket and the smell of burning human flesh dominated the city for months, as more than thirty-thousand plague victims had flesh reduced to ash. A second wave of plague from Chinese merchant ships added another thirty thousand Bangkok-area victims a year later. Stroll in slowly, and look around, as you will have no alternative but to pass through the stone-floored courtyards covering mass bone crypts (Buddhist cremation is low-temperature, leaving bones behind), and along the length of the burial walls built from the very bones of cremated plague victims, most unidentified. The vegetation has done its best to soften these marks of devastating human tragedy, but the almost overgrown feel only drapes a palpable pall about the place. It has a history of construction mishaps and mystery as long as your arm, and but for Allied intervention, might well have been destroyed in a planned bombing by the Japanese in World War II. You will feel every bit of its history coming in this way. The squeamish and those looking for no drama might best enter from the West. Walk through the grounds and reach the bottom of the mount, and you will find a coiled snake wrapped around the hill in the form of a long stairway leading to the top. The hundreds of stairs are painted red with non-slip paint, and feature risers roughly nine inches high but with three-foot treads. It is difficult to get a steady rhythm on stairs whose queer geometry seems designed to match no human stride, but perhaps this only emphasizes the dozen or more built in excuses to linger on the way to the top. You will find alcoves with small benches, the meditative melodies of a small well landscaped waterfall, misters, and a wide platform with temple bells to ring. As you rise, the views of the city became more impressive. The Golden Mount’s 89 meter height made it Bangkok’s tallest structure from its inception until the late 1970s, and even half way up, the view is impressive.The top tier of the Golden Mount well-deserves its name. As you reach the tiled cement platform at the top of the stairs, should you do so between say 10:00am and 3:00pm, you are likely to feel a palpable increase in temperature, the result of the sun’s blinding reflection from the thirty foot gold-leafed Chedi sitting atop its even larger box-shaped plastered pediment. From here, the city views do not disappoint. Walking inside the pediment reveals a more or less windowed structure with exhibits and the occasional Monk holding forth. And of course, in the center of the pediment structure is housed an argon-filed steel box holding bits of the hair, scalp and clothing of The Buddha, brought from the ruins of a Himalayan monastery on the India-Nepali border in 1899. This is a place of deep significance to Buddhists, who often use the trip up as a kind of purification rite. Prior to about 2002, the entrance into the chedi base above was a small wooden ladder, though lately it has become a tightly-spiraling staircase. This takes you up the last fifteen feet to the gold of the chedi itself. This is not for the disabled!From the very top, the breeze and views are wonderful, even on a hazy day, and there are few places better suited to watching the Cumulo-Nimbus clouds of the rainy season build and drop their watery burdens. I love the view from here, and suggest most of you will too. It is worth the moderate exercise and the heat to take in this place fully!

not that impressed. didn't quite live up to the hype, to me anyway. Seems like its frequented by more actual worshippers than tourists, which was interesting. A bit inconvenient to get to, and can be missed.

Some tips on what to expect and how to stay cool on the way there.. Start from Fort Mahakan (see route by water bus later in this report) and you should be there in under 10 minutes. As you know the heat and humidity means travel is sweaty so here is one route to keep the travel to a minimum. You read it here first! You will see the white painted stucco temple from the bridge at fort Mahakan. Take the small bridge towards the Temple of the Golden Mount. Look out for the wide open gates on the left. and cirulate antiiclockwise. Once through the gates you circulate anticlockwise until you get to the stairs up. Entry 20 Baht per adult. The first delight is small steps for 'little people' all the way to the top.On the way up there are little water falls and vapourised water spraying out, with the intent to refresh you whilst climbing. Eventually you come to a higher intermediate level. I noticed children and teenagers going to ring the prayer bells, bong, bong bong. Everyone including the women enjoy this experience but respect the buddhists who come here to ring a bell and expects God to hear their prayers and send out good reverberations into society around. You know Catholics have special moments like this when the Host is held aloft and the communion bell is rung. They believe that the host is turning into the body and blood of the Lord Jesus Christ. A very special moment when you are all down on your knees. Now back to the climb, I did this climb at 11 am and do not do this one in the afternoon when the heat will get you in summer time. The elderly and children over 5 will manage this climb in say 15 minutes easily .... just stop and rest when you need to. No pressure.As you near the top the photo spots get better but wait until the top. By know you are climbing around a white painted (plastered?) conical mount. At the top you go inside and there are fans blowing. Lovely cooling air. You can buy drinks, souvenirs and incense sticks and kneel at the shrines. There are seats, not a lot of them, and open windows, shuttered if their is a downpout and in May - August they frequently occur but never last too long. At this level there is one part in the centre of the building which you take your shoes off to visit. It is the point of the Shrine, which is to venerate the relics of what they call the Lord Buddha. He may be a lord but there is only One Lord of Lords.Now for a few of you the climb stops here but let me encourage you to go one level higher. In the right hand corner of the buidling (think about where you entered is a very short but very steep set of steps. Very short but mind your head as the climb is so steep you will be looking a the steps, holding the handrail and not thinking about bumping your head. The Thai branch of Buddhism has a lovely idea for making the steps so steep. The principal is that one should be on your hands and knees in the presence of God. Kneeling in western culture is the same. We are showing humility to an all powerful (El Shaddai) God who neverless has our good at heart.OK you reached the top in under 1 minute and now you are out on a top 4 sided balcony with a Stupa (conical) at the centre.Enjoy the views, then sit down and relax and study the worshippers here. I notices as many young as old people here and yes us westerners brought our children here. Very good to have them in church. Be discreet as you watch the buddhists kneel and prostrate themsleves all to the audio (hifi) chanting of monks piped over a loudspeaker system. move around and sit down again and see the alms given to God, ....paper money offerering tied to 'clothes lines'. Watch worshippers go to the side shrines in the corners and kneel and speak to their God. Remember Buddha was an enlightened one and never claimed to be God but only to point the way.The last treat at this level. There are two giant gongs. (Remember the rank adverts at the start of a film in cinemas?) Well everyone can take a turn at using the clothed hammer to strike the gong.This level is a hive of activity at most times of the day but you leave with a sense of wonder and supernatural peace.Now the way out is again a short but very steep stairway down in the opposite corner to that which you used on the way up. Back into the shopping/Buddha relics area. Do not forget to refresh yourself with a drink or icecream if the heat has gotten to you.A very important point. I did not use toilets at this level so I do not know if they are their but I know they are at the bottom so use them on the way up and way down.Once outside again little steps and prayer bells every know and again. Bong.Bong. Bong.Be comforted as God knows your every thought and He does hear and care.Some great photos of climbing plants which cover the trees can be seen on the way down. I saw a broad leaf (light green) and a flower that looked like a purple convovulus.... very pretty. Near the bottom you come to a narrow set of steps but a good handrail so they are not difficult.At the bottom a small shrine where you can go in and pray, offer incense.Beware you think you have come back to the entrance but not so. I followed the crowd but went onto the wrong exit. Never mind as it added to the adventure but took me nearly 20 minutes to get back to the water taxi and fort Makahan. The solution is when at the shopping level look out if all the windows and study the road layout beneath you.Enjoy and may you know Our Lord's blessing on your life. This attraction was the highlight of the day Oh by the way once back to fort Mahakan (under 10 minutes) you will walk as quickly as a taxi. The Tuk Tuks also get stuck in frightful traffic congestion so if you are going to come by road then get a motor cycle taxi. Do your research first though, agree the price at the start and this method is not recommende for women on their own.There are a number of other attractions nearby all within walking distance but allow 4 hours and dress in shorts and a tee shirt, all of which attire was accepted at the Temple of the Golden Mount.This is definitely not for someone in a wheel chair. Sorry.Now this attraction is nowhere accessible by car or train so a further recommendation on how to get to The temple as follows. You will need a map to make sense of the next part but bear in mind, 10 minutes walk up Ratchadamnoen Nok Avenue going north will bring you to the Ministry of Tourism and there are lots of maps and books for free there.You will need to decide from there do you go north to The Boxing Stadium, Marble Temple and Vimanmek Palace and throne hall or retrace your steps to fort Mahakan as that is the easiest way back to the BTS. BTS is very efficient and has topclass airconditioning once you are one the train.A suggested rout to The temple of the Golden Mount.Train it to BTS Ratchathewi (Bearing line) then walk back towards the canal bridge (low level). Say 200 metres south to the southwest side of the canal bridge over Khlong Saen Sab. Once down the steps you are under the 'belly' of the bridge and there is a tiny market or set of stalls, walk west away from the bridge just a few yards into the stalls and you will see the opening to the jetty (landing station for the the water bus). The water bus comes along say every 10 minutes in daylight but I am told stops by 7pm. You will take the water bus going west and you pay 10 baht per head. Be positive do not ask questions just proffer the correct money when the bus conductor walks along the side of the boat to you. It is an easy journey and you go all the way to the little termini. It is obvious as everyone gets off. Some good photos and excitement if you have video. Noise water gushing against the prow. I tell you when two water taxis pass each other the boat rocks for a few minutes afterwards. As the boat picks up speed some side curtains lift up to protect you from spray but you will want to hold them down if you want the photographs.Whilst at speed on the canals (khlongs) there is a pleasantly refreshing breeze.Get to know how to recognise the landing stage for the BTS before you take the water bus. It is easy you are going to look for a high level concrete bridge up above you. You could also count the road bridges. Be ready to get on and off as the water bus does not delay for anyone.Now look out for a small 'running board' on the inside of the bulwark as it helps lower your step down onboard and once on board you can stand alongside the housing (covering for the engine) so you get the best shots. Best not to cramp your style by sitting in the middle of a seating row.By the way the end of the line is Fort Mahakan.Be blessed and remember the bells, the bells and know they toll for you.Chris

Nice view looking down or looking up. It has nice views of the city from the top which is quite a walk. But the area around is small so it's not tiring to walk around. When I passed by the area in the evening I saw the top was lit up and I found it a very nice view from the ground.From Khao San Road,Soi Rambuttri or Phra Arthit Road, take bus no. 15. ( you can see it from afar but get down the bus when you see it up closer)From MBK (side of National Stadium) take bus no. 47 or 15.

The aura. The view from the top was excellent and also the theme throughout the ascent. The path up was very delicately made up with statues of mythological characters, flora and fauna,artificial mists ,artificial water falls etc.

Amongst the best views in Bangkok!. This was another stop on our first day in Bangkok. If you happen to be in the area or just planning a trip to Bangkok I suggest placing this site on your list of attractions. The Buddhist temple is another great experience that I would recommend for anyone that wants to be engulfed in this rich culture. Yes the climb to the top can be painful if it’s too hot and the shop was a bit too commercial for me. Yet, the view of Bangkok is spectacular from here!

Gorgeous stupa and view from the top!. It's a gorgeous place. It's about a temple on the top of a mountain, with a big golden stupa at the top, and a fantastic aereal view of Bangkok. You have to go up some stairs, which can be hard on a hot day in Bangkok. After that, you can have some lunch in a family house right across the street of the entrance of the temple, where they treat you as family and make you home-made tasty food.
Go for the view. Great view from the top. You aren't attacked by sprukers. Shop at the top is a bit of a put off. If you are in the area definitely worth a visit.

Nice. Bangkok view from above is nice, there're pretty flowers and lots of bells for rituals (I suggest to not ring them since it might not be appropriate), the stairs aren't so steep or too high so it was really nice to visit.
Interesting temple. Slightly commercial in nature. This was still an educational experience for us, as we were interested in buddism. Also, a very nice view from the top of all of central Bangkok.
beautiful. great views of bangkok.. beautiful wat. wide stairs to climb to top. great views of bangkok. lots of opportunities for photos inside and outside. must visit.
Fantastic panorama. I would say it is one of the "must visit" places in Bangkok. Amazing city panoramas from the top, quite and impressive atmosphere.

Well worth a visit. Although there are many stairs to climb they are of very small gradient and wind their way leisurely up around the Mount which makes it an easy climb. Artificial fog creates a mist amongst the lush vegetation, bells and Buddha. The view at the top is a great view across the seemingly never ending Bangkok skyline.

huge golden Buddha. Went there randomly . We saw the temple of course climbed the stairs. the atmosphere there is so peaceful. so many fountains and little statues on the way up. but the most beautiful surprise was this huge golden Buddha maybe 3 metres tall ...

Great view from the top. Its not one of the top 5 attractions in Bangkok so if your time is limited then you should give this a miss.
However if you have time on your hands and you don't mind a climb, then you will be rewarded with a spectacular view of the Bangkok skyline.

another must visit attraction in Bangkok. Enjoyed the temple and the picturesque view from the top of the "mount". A gentle walk up to the mount on the neatly spaced steps... Luckily we had no crowds at all when we went visiting. Buddha's relics are preserved in an urn at the Golden Mount (Wat Saket). Strangely finding a cab / taxi back from there to Pratunam was just not possible as cab drivers refused !! Had to come back in a tuk tuk ....

Great view of Bangkok. Arrived here on the first full day, as part of one of the tuk-tuk tour scams. A great view of the city, and some cool statues and other things to see. 20 bhat "donation" was needed to enter inside on the top level. It was a bit of a hike up the steps, so for kids or elderly, be prepared.

Visit if in Bangkok for 5+ days-Great View/Workout. The Golden Mount is a worth a visit if you're in Bangkok for 5 or more days. But if your time is precious, save your efforts for things like the Bangkok "Top 3" - Temple of Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew), Temple of Reclining Buddha (Wat Po), Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun). Golden Mount as a sight/site pales in comparison to those Bangkok "Biggies".PLUSES: The climb is a gentle ramp that curves around the mount, taking you through a verdant micro-jungle at the bottom, past a series of massive bells which you're welcome to ring, adding to the atmosphere. The whole climb is a great workout! The golden stupa atop the mount is an amazing, almost blinding sight up close in the daylight. Best to sit quietly for awhile and watch the many local Thais (who very much outnumber tourists) make their pilgrimage as they walk clockwise around the stupa as they pray. The view of Bangkok from the top is stupendous. Overall, a very atmospheric, genuine encounter as you share with the Thais their spiritual experience.MINUSES: though it's a gentle upward grade, there are still lots of steps, so guaranteed you will be sweatin' like a sow by the time you get to the top! There are no particularly interesting sights INSIDE any of the buildings (no amazing Buddha statues).TIPS: If you've already made your way to the Golden Mount, explore the main street running north-south beside the entrance (Boriphat Road) where you will see more than a dozen open-air woodworking shops. Amazing craftsmanship, often executed by tradespeople right before your eyes! Alluring wood aroma all around. Also, if you walk south on Boriphat Road to first main interesection, turn right (west) on Thanon Bamrung Mueang and cross the canal, on the south side you'll see more than a dozen "Buddha" shops, selling every conceivable kind of Buddha statue in every size known to man. Very atmospheric, totally NON touristy (this is where Thais come for their religious icon purchases). Loved it.Due to the very interesting neighbourhood around Golden Mount, I rate this attraction 4-stars (Very Good). If not for the cool 'hood, would only rate Golden Mount 3-stars (Average).

A Must See in Bangkok. Neither the largest nor the most beautiful temple in Bangkok but for sure one of the most inspiring and non touristic ones. Especially during the week and of course outside public holidays the Golden Mount provides a great experience. There wont be many people and those who made it here have really a kind of interest beyond making pictures only. The pure amount of steps you have to manage to come to the temple itself provides a first kind of quality gate if you really want to go here. No shops or sth comparable other than one at the top destroy the authentic atmosphere. You have an amazing view over Bangkok form the top. Not only the skyline and the kings palace but especially the view over the local places close by is sth unique. Once at the top you can buy (one shop must be there...) a kind of bell where you can write your wishes and place it at the very top at the golden mountain itself. A very nice thing to do while enjoying the place. The Golden Mountain might be a good stop between City and Kings Palace. Hardcore travelers might even want to walk from here to Kings Palace but thats quite a walk. Enjoy.

Beautiful, but not particularly worth it. Wat Saket is a beautiful temple for sure. However, I was only in Bangkok for 3 days and I felt that my time could have been better spent. The temple and it's surrounding area is beautiful but the climb (while short and not particularly physically exerting) is not as breathtaking or exciting as you may imagine it to be. If you have a limited amount of time in Bangkok I would definitely recommend just admiring it from afar.

Picturesque view (of not-so-picturesque Bangkok!). Nice, long walk up to the summit, passing many different interesting sights (including many bells and gongs!)View from the top is amazing. Bangkok might not be the prettiest city in the world, but to see it in all its splendour is definitely worth climbing to the top of this temple.Great ambience, definitely worth a couple of hours of your time. Getting to there (if you're walking) is interesting too, as it seems to be near either temples too so you'll likely spot a lot of monks!

Worth an hour or so.. This is worth a trek to, and up. It is free unless you want to go inside at the top, but for most non-Buddhists, people the main attraction is the view, and the various grottoes etc. on the way up and down.It really isn’t much of a hike, so even if you are fairly unfit, or it is very hot, it should be manageable for most people.
Good view. Nice pagoda but quite a climb when the temperature is high .Great views and photographic opportunities from the top.

Go For the View. I liked this temple; although, it's hardly spectacular. The view at the top of the main reason to visit. There are some good food vendors down below. Take the khlong taxi to get there.

Favourite of the temples. Obviously temples proliferate in Bangkok - if you are picking which ones to see, this was my favourite. Not as much to see as others but very peaceful, with panoramic views of the city
Nice view of the city. Visit this temple for a great view of the city. Temple grounds are very peaceful and good for a nice relaxing moment in the hectic city.
Beautiful temple,great views.. Worth the steps to walk up, really good views of the city, good breezes & peaceful surroundings. Ring the bells for good luck.
If you not scared to climb in the heat.... If you not scared to climb in the heat, then go to the Golden Mount. Very beautiful view of the city. Nice gong you can it and hear great sound!
Good exercise to go to the top!!. The walk up to the top was not bad at all although it appeared to be at first. Nice scenery at the top, able to see all around the city.

Amazingly beautiful temple. Worth the hike up the steps on a hot day! You will be rewarded by a beautiful view of Bangkok, cool breezes and a temple of significance to acquire merit by giving offerings to the Buddha and other icons there. It can get busy but don't let that put you off, you will be rewarded by the effort to make it to the top! But, please as others have written, please show some respect as this is a working temple, and wear some clothes that cover the shoulders, not like the troop of bikini and short shorts clad eastern european women that mortified the monks and the true worshipers ...

Great views, nice temple.. The temple is in a great spot and very active with worshippers and monks, this should be born in mind because I was mortified to see the troops of nearly naked tourists clambering up. Come on guys have a little respect eh.

worth the visit. We found this place by accident, and thought it was a highlight of our trip. A very peaceful and tranquil place. There is a nice takeaway shop to grab a nice cool ice cream. A fantastic view once up the top.
Great Views. Worth a climb if you are passing. Good views across the other city sights. Probably not worth allocating more than about 1 hour but loads of other things to see in the area.

Great views at the top.. If you like temples with great views, you will probably like this one. It does have a fair amount of stairs to the top, so you must be able bodied to see this one. There are some beautiful bells placed along the way up and down that you can ring for clearing bad spirits and good luck. A nice place. I spent about forty minutes here and saw all of it.

A must see. The golden mount is a great wat to visit! There are nice areas to relax, the steps to it provide a great exercise area for some locals and of course tere are actual busdhists walking around. Don't forget to go on the rooftop and hit the gong :)

Lots of steps but if done with ease its easy with great views at top!!. Visited the golden mount as last stop on our day 1 BKK holiday on Urban Adventures Tuk Tuk Experience. Interesting history re crematorium across the road at base of climb. Big centipedes can be found all the way up, with bells that can be chimed half way up for good luck! At top a few souvenir trinkets can be bought, with a tiny staircase (watch your head!) to great views & statues on roof. Worth a visit!

Worth a visit if you love seeing a city from a vantage point. It's worth a visit if you love seeing a city from a vantage point. The temple itself is not really impressive in my opinion - so only go if you're keen on the view (which isn't spectacular).
Old temple of Bangkok. The best view of old city from the top of the golden mountain at Wat Saket, nearby it has the Ban Bat to visit for your tour from Temple.

An out of the way treasure. Wat Saket always appears in the guidebooks as a highly rated "thing to do" but hardly any tourists seem to go there because its a bit out of the way. It's really worth a visit. If you happen to be staying in Sukhumvit, a fun way to get there is on the public transport klong boats on the Saen Saeb canal. It costs about 16 baht from the wharfs at soi 3 (Nana) or soi 21 (Asoke) to Wat Saket, which is the end of the line, noting however that you have to change boats at Tha Pratunam. To get to Wat Saket from the intersection you walk a few hundred metres down Thanon Mahachai, which is devoted to cabinetmaking and lumber shops, which are interesting in themselves. Wat Saket is quite a climb, but it is worth it. You get a great 360 degree view of Bangkok from the top. The Wat is the centre of the Loi Krathong celebrations which take place in November.

Good views from the top.. It's a fair walk up to the top and tourists should not be short of breath. Plenty of places to rest if you are getting breathless - big gongs on the way up that make a fabulous noise when struck correctly. As this is a place of pilgrimage for many Buddhists it should be treated accordingly although there do not appear to be any dress restrictions. A 1 hour stay is more than enough.
Good View, Lots of Steps and Bells. Didn't really know what to expect of the Golden Mount. Turns out to be a lot of steps (100 ish maybe more). Views of Bangkok from the top are very good.

Deeply spiritual site. We came here at the tail-end of the Thai New Year celebrations so it was swarming with locals which added a very spiritual element to the site. They were ringing bells, lighting incense sticks and praying. When you enter the site off of the side street, go to the right and then climb the stairs. If you go to the left, you will be going up the down staircase! There are several levels to this complex, so make sure you keep going up. You don't need to take off your shoes here either (according to the signs). The view from the top is amazing. Definitely worth a visit.
Steep climb but great views. The 360 degree views of Bangkok are worth the climb. There is a nice cafe near the start (50 m up) with good food and clean toilets.

Magic !. Best OF the best ! Unique temple with monks praying , no tourists around , no business oriented , easy steps to climb up , ring the bells , hit the gong , 360 degres view on Bangkok...just woaaaaaaw really must see !
Wrong location on map. It is not the right location on map. Im a local resident but dont know how to relocate this place on the map. Pretty new for tripadvisor. . Who know how to do?

Great view from the top.. This place is best visited on a very clear day because the views from the tops are amazing. The stairs are not very difficult to climb, and even the walk up is enjoyable. The temple itself is nothing much, but the view is definitely worth it. Its free to enter.

Beautiful view of the city. Ring the bells as you walk up the steps to the top of this temple. The views you get from this building are spectacular and although it's quite small in comparison to other temples in the city, it is very unique and even boasts ashes of the original Buddah.

Great escape and the best views. Wat Saket is a really special place. We visited first thing in the morning and it wasn't busy at all which was nice for a change. The climb up is really enjoyable as the steps aren't that steep, there are also small Buddha statues, little waterfalls and bells. When you get to the top you'll be amazed with the views and tranquility of the place. It's also not as touristy so it definitely is a nice escape from all the Bangkok madness.

A great view!. A definite must. I had missed it on my previos visit and make a point to visit it this last trip, and am certainly glad I made it. The Wat provides teriffic views of the city, and is located in a charming section of the city just off one of the khlongs. It is quite a peaceful place. Be prepared for the hike up, though. It is a faily steep climb.

Climb Up The Steps To Show Your Devotion. If you want to visit the golden mountain, you must be prepared to climb up hundreds of steps to reach the peak. It was not tiring as the steps were not steep and were gradual.Once at the peak, you can feel the wind and see the scenery. Climb another steep steps further up and you will see relics of buddha and the golden dome.I would recommend this temple to others.

nice place to enjoy sunset. It 's a shame it closed a bit too early but the views are amazing from the top of the stairs. If the weather is not too foggy, you can really appreciate the immensity of the city

Love this Wat! The stairs are good exercise!. I enjoyed visiting this Wat tremendously. My first thought of having to climb stairs to see the temple was like "Oh are you kidding?! Under this heat?" But I was determined and promised myself I would gave my best. There's a saying 'Before the reward there must be labor'. When I arrived there, I was so excited to see the temple up there that I quickly dismissed the idea of being lazy and I know the reward would be worth every climb. When I saw the stairs, I thought "Well, it's not bad at all!" The stairs were flat and not steep like in Wat Arun. And there's place to rest too. While you're climbing, you can go slow and enjoy the view as you go along.There are bells and gongs halfway through the stairs. Make sure you hit them. It's fun!The reward was of course...the view of Bangkok...BEAUTIFUL!!!The Buddha inside is beautiful. There are shops selling Buddhism books, accessories etc. And you can go upstairs to the rooftop where you can view an even better 360 degrees view of Bangkok. Make sure you visit this temple! The stairs are good exercise :-)

Fabulous. My number two of the best Wats in Bangkok. Take a taxi on a clear day and enjoy the climb to the top for a stunning view of the city. There is an enclosed area at the top to enjoy the view and chill.

Lovely views of the city, and very beautiful. Only takes an hour out of your day, and worth the visit! Really beautiful climb up with waterfalls and nature. The views from the city are also very beautiful! When I visited the Monks were performing a ritual around the bell which was very interesting to see!

Not a Must-see, but Worth a Visit. A small cover fee is asked at the entrance to access the rooftop, where you'll have a pretty nice 360 degree view of the city. The stairway to the top is also very nice, full of plants and small fountains. A nice promenade up.

Great views, not pricey, worth a look!. By the way people were talking on here I was a bit concerned with the stairs having a broken toe. They aren't large steps so easy to climb and wasn't hard at all! Don't be concerned with stairs! lovely views of the city, small donation required, drinks and souvenirs at the top. Definitely worth going to!

TERRIFIC VIEWS FROM THIS WAT!. I really enjoyed my visit to Wat Saket - The Golden Mount, I think because of the climb some people are put off visiting, I would say don't be it is well worth the steps up for the stunning views & you get to ring the bells for good fortune! Close by there is the shop in the back street where they make the original Buddhist Monks alms bowls in the traditionl way & this is certainly worth a visit too.
Long way up. very nice temple on the mountain and the view over Bangkok is great too. You also have a n occason to ring all the bells on the way.

this was my favorite Wat in Bangkok. Compared to the other major tourist attractions in Bangkok this one was quite peaceful. only a handful of tourists. The climb up to the Wat is substantial but the view of the city is spectacular and worth every step.

A very nice place!. This was a good wow. and even this is in the middle of the city, the place was so quiet and nice. Its a bit of walk up to the top, but it was worth it, just to look at the details of the scenerey alone.Up on the top you will get a very nice view of the city itself, and nearby attractions (combine the tour with this, and take a canal tour after you are done!)

many steps but nice view "beware pick pockets". a bit off a trek up many steps before u go down a narrow passage beware pick pockets here they rub up against people ! lord buddha relics in the mount ! a nice hour or two

Lots of steps, not so impressive. Did the climb, thought that there would be more to see at the top, lots of bells on the way up and I rang a few. Was unsure why at top, I could leave my shoes on as everywhere else it was take them off
A must see. Yet another amazing temple in Bangkok and once your at the top you have some great views over Bangkok and its free to enter.
shady business. too many touts in and around the temple area. Nice to look at from afar, nothing to see once you're there
Interesting Place. The buddhist worship place , with lot of piligrims....The view on the city is great from here! Make sure to wear comfortable shoes, as they are lot of stairs here !

A Gem in the Middle of Bangkok. Nothing to dislike. You are greeted with a wonderful view overlooking the entire city when you walk the circular path on the top. Worth the time and energy. Also, the bells to ring on the way up are delightful and hopefully enjoyable to most people who hear the vibes.

Worth viviting. Have a look at it during the day, which is nice, with very good views over bangkok from the top.
And then you come back for a thai festival in the night, when the area around the golden mountain turns into a festival area.

Cool views!! Fun trip up!. I really liked this one because it broke up the monotony of just walking in a Wat. You climb up a lot of stairs (easy cling though) and are rewarded with beautiful panoramic views of the city!!! The walk up itself is fun as there are beautiful gardens and you can ring bells and gongs on the way! (I mean who doesn't like banging a gong!?!:) another selling point besides its beauty is its free!!!!:) definitely worth the hike up!!!:):)

Good views, boring temple. The inside, which requests (more demands), a donation wasn't that impressive, Buddhas and gift shops. The views from the top were pretty good though. If you go in, make sure to go up the narrow stairs to the very top with the gold Chedi and the more interesting statues. If you're trying to save money, then you can go almost to the top and walk around the area around the entrance where you get practically the same views (the donation isn't requested until you enter the building at the top). As others mentioned, there's about 700 stairs. Free, somewhat clean bathrooms on the bottom. Don't miss hitting the huge gong on the way down.
Golden Mount. I like this place because after the long climb up a lot of steps the peace at the top is refreshing and invigorating to the soul The history is interesting also and the view is great

Nice view on top, much less touristy. Took a 60 baht tuktuk to Golden Mount (later realized it was a tourist tuktuk which makes many stops at tailer and jewelry shops). Not a lot of people at the Wat; entrance was free. Walked up the stairs to the top (nice breeze at the top); ring the bells. Well worth the visit. Visit time: 1 hour.

A Beautiful and Peaceful Site. It was a walk to find the Golden Mount and another climb up many stairs to get to the top, but so worth it. I arrived in late afternoon and watched the sunset from the top. It was beautiful. The whole hillside with the bells lining parts of the walkway is very lovely.
Nice view of Bangkok. It's a great place to view Bangkok in the top of the mount. Not too many other surprising things to visit. The wind is very strong on the top. It's a place worth a visit.

Surprising. Went there randomly . We saw the temple of course climbed the stairs. the atmosphere there is so peaceful. so many fountains and little statues on the way up. but the most beautiful surprise was this huge golden Buddha maybe 3 metres tall... Just amazing and ... free ....

Great views of Bangkok. Don't expect to be able to see the stupa at the top of the wat after walking up the stairs. There is a small buddha and a shop but not much else. The views over Bankok made the effort worth while.

Disappointing view. We climbed this in the hope of seeing a view of Bangkok which engaged our interest but the view was fairly banal of skyscrapers and nondescript buldings, although the immediate location of the Golden Mount was interesting.
Very impressive!! Shady escape.. Golden Mount was a nice escape from hectic Bangkok. It is a winding path of stairs that are mostly shaded. Great photo ops!!

worth the climb!. Take the river canal boat to Leefard pier and take a short walk about 10 minutes away,passing by the Golden Mount fire station.The panoramic view up there is worth the climb, which isn't that steep anyway. It's relatively quiet compared to the other temples.There is an ATM machine available in the temple's resting area and a small restaurant right below the temple.

Definitely worth it. It is a place to visit. You have to climb to the top and ring the bells one by one. Listen to their sound and be transported in the atmosphere of the place. Beautiful view from the top.
Lovely views. Lots of steps to the top, so not suitable for everyone. Lovely views from the top. A good place to visit.

Wat Saket and The Golden Mount. Climb the mount: it's worth it for the views over the city and of the surrounding Wats. The temple Wat Saket, being adjacent, is also well worth the visit. It is very quiet compared to Wat Po and the Grand Palace.

Worth a Trip. It was great to be able to go somewhere and not pay an entrance fee or be hassled and not in a huge crowded area. We took our time climbing to the top, from here you can see nearly all of Bangkok, the skyrise buildings and in contrast the old houses. There are a lot of bells on two of the levels and it was fun to give them a good ring. I was surprised that no one took their shoes off inside the Temple at the top. Everything seems so white and clean. We enjoyed our visit.
Nice view. After so many many stairs you can see Bangkok city from top, it's quite nice and the entrance is free
Beautiful temple.. Nice little walk up the stairs of this magnificent temple. You'll get a nice view on other temples from the top.
Oasis in the City. It felt like a retreat in the city. It was beautiful, great view of the city and a fabulous breeze. Very pretty.

Famous during Loy Krathong Festival. I often went there when I was little. There were lots of events set up especially the buddhist related ones such as Loy Krathong. Many couples go there for the traditional Thai party. There are lots of Thai games and shops in the area to remind of the traditional way of enjoying the time inside the temple.

Great views over the city. I have been to Bangkok many times but my last visit in January I went to Wat Saket for the first time and am sure it wont be the last. I loved the views of the city from the top - a great place to spend some time.

"Spectacular view". Spectacular view of the city could be seen from the top of the Golden Mount. It is really worth it! It is situated about 1/2 hour walk through the traffic from Khao San road. In the evening, you could also see the skyline and the city being lighted up.

give good wishes to the wind. before the skyscrapers were, the golden mount was the highest from human beings constructed building in bangkok. we arrived in the morning time, because this magic place is very frequentated from tourists the whole day. the view over bangkok and its skyline is extraordinary and every step up to the mountain worth very much. around the golden mount a monastery is located, in which it is possible to buy small bells for low money. with these bells the people can give wishes to the wind. they write their wishes on the bell with oil pens before they move up to the temple. at least the bells are hung on the outside front of the temple and the wind takes the wishes with itself to fullfill them. a very nice custom which should be copied.
Start your Bangkok tour here. Nice temple with panoramic view of Bangkok. Start your tour here, because climbing to the top of mount is not for tired people
Great view over the city. The huge gongs are fun the use and you are allowed to in this temple. The view is amazing, and make sure you chat to a monk, they are super nice people.

Like walking up to heaven. The Golden mount is a must see while in Bangkok. There are stairs that go around the mount, when you first start your journey you go through beautiful foliage making it feel like you are in a rainforest. As you get near the top and are peering around the stairs light will shine in your eyes making you feel like you are walking "towards the light." Once you get to the top there are some Buddhas and a little gift store in the temple area and then you take a very narrow staircase to the Golden Mount. The view of Bangkok is great and the Golden Pagoda is huge. It is a great place to stop for about an hour.

Bangkok city panorama. i dont mind the walk, or the traffic to get to the gate of Golden Mountain. They worth it. under the city's bodhi trees, bringing inner peace and comfort. my personal spot in any season. but can be difficult during the rain. so check the weather before you go.

It's not a mountain but it's worth. It's a little hill in flat Bangkok and after climbing it you find yourself in....a mountain. That is because Bangkok is flat, very flat. From the Temple on its top it's possible to see the whole Bangkok. The rtemple itself is inspiring, beautiful. Do not miss it....make an offer.

The_Golden_Mount_Wat_Saket-Bangkok.. The Golden Mount there are more Temples which you should visit first but from the Golden Mount you do get a decent view of the city also use it as a land mark to go on water taxis in the Main Khlong (canal)

5.5 tons of Gold. Apart from the amazing amount of gold here - 5.5 tons of it....the overall experience is not exceptional. Steep steps - but if you are handicapped there is an elevator available (you'll have to ask for directions). Neighborhood is adjacent to Chinatown - but not particularly picturesque. The Temple enshrining the Golden Buddah itself is not "ancient" - but fairly new - refurbished a few years ago - worth a visit if you have the time, but I'd place this one a few rungs done on the must see list if you have limited time
Great views. Great views of the old sity but the inside is a bit average - doesn't feel like a temple, more like an old souvenier shop.

Great Views. I ended up at this place purely by accident, I had asked the motorcycle driver to take me to the Golden Buddha, but I ended up at the Golden Mount instead. Well, as I was there thought I'd take a look. Glad I did. You do have to climb a of stairs to get to the top but the slope is fairly gentle so it's not a hard climb. The views from the top are nice and you can see much of the city from up above. The temple itself and the drums and gongs are also interesting and if you're lucky you'll see some monks beating away on one of the drums. This wat is also close to other attractions within walking distance. There's a klong nearby where you can jump in a boat and see something that way, there are other temples within 10 minutes walk, and Democracy Monument is about 15 minutes away. All in all a good way to kill an afternoon. There is a small fee, Bt10 once you get to the top and go inside the building up there.

Nice to See but too many stairs!. It is so so experience if you are not much into historical places. You need to take too many stairs to get there but you will not find a very special thing at the top!
Many steps to climb. Be ready to climb lot`s of step! But the view is worth the tour. You can see the full Bangkok view for free. There is lots of bell to play :-)
Great climb!. The Golden Mount was a neat location and a great climb to the top. You get some spectacular views of Bangkok and my children really enjoyed ringing all the bells.
Best thing are the views. Not impressive compared to other temples. On the way up you get really nice views of the city. Nice to do but only if you have more than 2 days in Bangkok.

Peace in a busy city. We walked up to the top of the mount, and loved the bells to be tolled along the way. Couldn't resist banging the gong either. Gave great views of the city, even though it was smoggy.

not much of a mountain but you will seeee. Liked: 1) you could see quite a bit of the city
2) had a very good mood/feeling
Careful you don't get scammed into the 5 attractions plus an unmentioned tailor and "tourist office" by the Tuk-tuk drivers.
These "tourist offices" are big bad scam artists.

if you like to walk a mountain. Many stairs will bring you up to the top of the Golden Mount.
Every now and then it comes a plateau where you can cling bells as the monks do.
At the top of the Golden Mount you will have a beautiful view!
It's really worth it if you can climb so many steps!

Great views and a cooling breeze. It's nice to just take a steady climb to the top to sit in the calmness with the ocassional Monk to keep you company. Great place to catch a breeze and take some interesting photo's

Fantastic view. Of course everybody will tell you that the view is fantastic, but please also think about the small symbolic and spiritual elements which you will find during your five minute climb up to the top of the temple. However this is a very well know temple, rather few tourists give it a visit so it’s certainly not so crowed as the grand palace.
nice view. One of the best attractions in Bangkok. No entry fee's, nice view from the top. Loads of things to see.

Magnificent and peaceful sunset.. I came back to Bangkok after a 10 day meditation retreat and thought what to do during the first afternoon. Was not in the mood to hit the malls or restaurants, still wanted some peace and quiet. So, I went to Wat Saket and it was a bliss. The mountain is open until 17:30 and they really start to kick people out closer to 6 p.m. This is a bit before the sunset but still gives you a lot of time to enjoy the setting sun and the views of colorful city.Above all I loved the tranquility, not many people were there surprisingly and one could fully relax, enjoy the views, meditate, walk around the Stupa on the top, breath in "fresh" air :).There is a cafe, toilets and souvenir shops on the way up - if anyone's interested. Otherwise, the area itself is nicely done - some small waterfalls, Buddha statues, bells which everyone likes to ring ... is it for good luck? :)I think it is a very special place to visit in Bangkok and the best is to come before sunset and count on 1-2 hours for the visit.

watch out for people trying to help. We took the water boat there, as soon as we got off a local guy tried to help us by showing us on map where everything is. He seemed just a passerby. Then he asked if we know about the govt special announcement of Bhat 50 only for today if we take tuk-tuk to see whole city. As the wat is closed now for special govt prayers and will open after mid day. Later he walked away and immediately a tuk-tuk guy came to ask if we want a round. We almost were about to sit in that tuk-tuk when we remembered the reviews by others for Thailand. So we decided to atleast go till Wat and see if it's open or not. So we walked a lil, reach Wat and it was Open!!!It's just a scam, they use that to take you to Gems Gallery as cabs and tuk-tuk guys get good commissions for bringing people there. They do not realize that they might earn a meal but our day gets wasted and whole schedule goes off track!!!

Nice view at sunset. The Wat is nice, though you don't need much time to look through it. The climb to the top of the Golden Mount is not too strenuous, and the views of the city are great, especially for sunset.

Great free panoramic views. Climbing this place is a great workout and your reward is fantastic views of the city. Maybe take one of the UV umbrellas the locals have to ward off the sun, because there's only shade on one side, remember.
Fantastic panoramic views of the city. There is no admission charge and the walk up the several flights of steps to the top of the monument are rewarded by the 360 degree views across the city

One of the must sees in Bangkok. Stunning views over the city and a fine atmosphere around the temple. Obviously you have the normal nuisance Tuk-Tuk drivers outside if you completely ignore them and smile then they know that you aren't interested.

Beautiful views. We had a great journey, using riverboats and seeing the real Bangkok, it was a very hot day, fortunately the steps are shallow, hundreds of them and the climb is worth it.The views are amazing and lots of beautiful nells and gongs enroute. Rude lady in gift shop, but well worth a visit
Wow what a hike. don't let the hike up all those steps stop you this place has a great view of the area. But the hike is best done in the morning or the midday sun will suck the life out of you.

A great view of Bangkok from the top. Because this temple was created by the 19th C king, we were taken to it. However it is not a beautiful structure in itself. But there is a panoramic view of Bangkok from the top. If you are short of time, rather focus on Wat Phra Kaeo and Wat Pho, which will give you a complete dose of great Bangkok temples.

Great views, great atmosphere. Def worth a trip. We took the river bus from the pier near Siam Centre which was great and an adventure in itself. The golden mount is just lovely and so atmospheric. Go for sunset. The views are amazing too.

Definitely worth seeing. You climb a lot of stairs to get to the top, but the journey along the way is beautiful and largely shaded. As you ascend you'll get several great panoramic views of the city. The area at the very top is the site of ongoing Buddhist devotion.

Nice temple, no entry, great view. As mentioned, there is nothing specific to see, but all in all, it´s somehow quiet up their, you have a good view over Bangkok and some steps to take, before you´re up. You can reach it by one of the water boats which is already an own experience. And include it as on part of a round trip through the heart of Bangkok.

The greatest temple view of Bangkok, period. Ok, it's an artificial hill but the temple is charming (yet underwhelming when compared to the What Pho or Phra Keo), the views are stunning and there are almost no crowds.Visit in the late afternoon and wait for the sunset. Breathe in the calm air before the evening, enjoy a gust of wind, see the skyscrapers in the distance, ring a bell, beat a gong.

Five star view of Bangkok. The Wat is interesting, but I cannot say it's the most amazing I've seen on my Thai travels, but what really wins the day and makes a visit well worth it is the fabulous 360 degree views of Bangkok. If you're coming from Siam Centre area, you can catch a longtail boat along the canal for about 20 baht one way and gets you there in about 7mins. The canal stop is near (and runs behind) the Jim Thompson house and you get off at the last stop for a quick 5 min walk across the canal to the Wat itself.
Wat Saket. This was an after thought But what a Great idea... I gotta say although we did alot of Wats each and everyone is different and amazing!!
the best view ever without paying.. There is a lot of stairs but when they are finished, you get the most amazing view. i was there in the morning it was cloudy but i was still satisfied.

Great view and nice climb. We were initially daunted by the 300+ steps but turned out they were very shallow steps and easy to climb. It was easy for my 4-year old son too. It was nice to ring the bells all the way to the top. The place was a bit smaller than we had imagined though. The cafe at the start of the climb was a nice little enclave and served nice coffee.
