average. not alot to say really! good views when you do reach the top. B warned there are alot of stairs to climb
Our first thai temple. the golden mound temple is worth seeing - in november 2012 it was free to go to the top, enjoy the view of the city and ring the bells.

View of the city. we were fortunate to be there just before a large festival was setting up. So not only did we get a great 360 degree view of the city, but also a feeling for a Thai festival with food, rides for children and everything else.

Worth a visit.... After a short walk from the Grand Palace, we rode a tuk-tuk over to the Golden Mount. It's an easy hike to the top, with a few places along the way to stop (and ring the bells!). The template at the top isn't the nicest you'll see in Thailand, but the view was incredible and worth the time on our trip.

Not the best for seeing a temple but the city view!. Climbing the steps with a beautiful view of Bangkok skyline was very nice. Seeing some budist priests with orange color clothes was also nice experience. There is a nice golden coated buddha statue on the top which is nice.

Golden temple..... with golden vistas. Having explored most of what Bangkok has to offer on the tourist trail, I decided to venture off the beaten track and explore some of the less well known temples in the city. Wat Saket or otherwise Golden Mount is worth the effort and as you approach it the view is spectacular. Golden Mount is a Buddhist temple and dates back to the Ayutthaya era, it is situated on a low hill crowned with a golden Chedi on the top.There are 318 steps to climb to reach the top, so going early is advisable. There are many thing to look at on route including Buddhist statues and bells. Entrance is free, but 5 Bart to enter the Chedi. And the opening times to the Golden Mount are from 9.00am-17.00pm.Once at the top the golden Chedi is quite spectacular and surprisingly peaceful, there are excellent views of Bangkok, as this once used to be the highest part of the city.Be aware though if you go in November this may coincide with Temple Fair (Loy Kratong) a ten day long festival which is a sacred pilgrimage to the Golden Mount and is incredibly busy.Golden Mount should be for any traveller who is looking for something new and a little off the tourist trail to explore.

Beautiful View. It was a long walk up stairs on top of the temple. I was hesitated to walk up but I made it. The view up there was so stunning. I could see old Bangkok area so far away sight. This is why people want to visit this temple. There are a lot of Thais come to pay respect to the Buddha image. I can touch the feeling of thier believes. I would recommend this temple to my friends to visit.

Just Beautiful. Wat Saket is located Between Briphat Road and Lan Luang Road, off Ratchadamnoen Klang Road in Bangkok. You can reach there by bus nos. 8,15, 47. It is open from 9am to 5pm.You have to climb aboout 320 steps to reach to the top of this temple from where you can have a 360degree view of Bangkok City. It is a low hill area with a gleaming gold chedi on it. Within, the 58-metre chedi houses a Buddha relic. Worshippers come here all year round. The temple also hosts an annual fair in November. Coloured lanterns, decorative flags, food vendors as well as games and rides bring the place to life. Crowds of worshippers, families and fair-goers pack the temple grounds from early evening to midnight for the entire week. There’s hardly room to walk. So plan to go as early as possible.Golden Mount Temple is an exception as you are allowed to walk with your shoes on.

the heart of Bangkok. I visited it by feet) Really - I went from the Wat Pho and go there crossind the Giant Wings and Wat Suthat (also very beautiful).
Here is about 300 stairs, and many view points. At every point there are some bells, that you may touсh for health of your family. The highest point is a huge golden chedy.
What a view.. It is a very nice park type Temple and is very pretty. It is quit a walk to the top but once your there what view. You can see all over bangkok from the top. And it is worth the walk.

One of the most beautiful temples of Bangkok. The Golden Mount is at first glance not as spectacular as the more popular systems, but should be in the tour program is no shortage. If you look at the system approaches, one can not detect the size of the plant first. In the one-way system (up a flight of stairs, down on the other side) will be funneled through the temple complex. What is particularly impressive is the large number of Thais who come here, it is really not a pure tourist destination.The Golden Mount is a bit out of the other main attractions of Bangkok, it is advisable to check with Klong taxi.
Wat Saket. Very interesting to see but is a popular spot and it may take some time to get to it depending on the time you go, getting there early is probably best, give your self 1-2 hours here.
A real treat!. Great views! Interesting stuff to look at. Fairly easy to get to using BKK and a taxi/tuktuk. GREAT for pics!

the best is the view of the city and the monks in orange clothes!. the temple is not "nice" compared to the others in town, but it is worthwhile to go up the "mountain". When we were there they were getting ready for a celebration and the monks were putting loads of pineapples, apples, flowers and other offerings to Buddha.

A different experience. I liked everything that I saw there.. Me and my family were brought there by our kind and close Thai friends and this was an experience of getting to know some of their culture and beliefs.. Very nice place, indeed..
Excellent. Very quiet and beautiful place. The bells are very old and have a certain vibration to it. Suggestion: Go as group so that you are not lost

Towering views of the city. Wat Saket or better known as the Golden Mountain is built on a man-made hill and the temple hall on the foot of the hill houses a big Buddha image called Luang Por Toh meaning Big Revered Father. Ascending the hill to the pagoda atop the summit there are many trees and shrines from family cremations placed beside the stairs. The Pagoda itself houses a rare Buddha relic and and can only be entered through a narrow passageway.However, the panoramic view from the platform around the pagoda is well worth the ascent!

my favorite temple. this temple is a bit out of the main beaten touristic road.. it is one of my favorite place in bangkok.. thai praying, farang discovering, nice mix.. Best time to go is before 5 pm... to enjoy the view and avoid the crowd.. Dont forget to ring the hundred bells on the way up, and to ring the other hundreds on the way down :)

Artificial mountain. One of my favourite places in Bangkok, l think I have been there 4 or five times. After a short climb over 318 steps you have a great view over the older part of Bangkok. I always find it very relaxing up there. Great for taking photographs, no entrance fee and mostly just a few visitors. It's not far from Kao San Road and close to Saen Sep Canal.
Worth the climb for great views!. Not as overrun as some of the more well-known and visited temples. Offers great views of the city and other temples after a relatively short climb up the stairs.

A lesser explored temple. This temple was not so busy when we visited, and therefore felt much more authentic. The walk to the top is hot work (in the humidity) but you'll be rewarded by some fantastic views!
Great view of the old city. Neat spot to check out the old city and get a view of the skyline. It was a good stop, a fun little hike to the top of the mountain and a neat place to visit

Worth every single step.... The temple dates back to the Ayutthaya era, when it was known as Wat Sakae. When Bangkok became the capital, King Rama I renovated the temple and gave it its present name.To get to the top you climb 800 steps and in a hot day its a challenge anyway you look at it. If you not push yourself too hard, you can enjoy the lucious green trees and plants that follows the big circle stairs, ring the bells and take some great shots. The panoramic view from the top of the Wat is the cherry of the pie, so just let that moment and the view take you a step closer to the heavens at least for a second, before you start your descending path to the ground..
What views. Great place to see, I had no idea what was going on in religious terms but it was great to watch it all and learn more about the way they live

nice view. nice view of the main stupa and the city area from the top of the hill.its very peaceful and quiet, very conducive for prayer and meditation when I went there. It was very hot and humid though.

Awesome temple. Climbing the 800 steps may be a bit of a challenge for people who have bad knees, but the reward is great! This was one of the places I really wanted to visit and it did not disappoint :-) After climbing the stairs you have a great view over Bangkok.

good experience climbing the little hill. good experience climbing the little hill to the temple to pray n see buddha statues.if u plan to get buddha statues / souveniers at the only souvenier stall, no bargaining allowed n the stall staff were impatient.

Worth Your While to Visit. The Golden Mount has an interesting and sacred history that is explained with various exhibits. It is a quiet oasis and provides a circular stairway rather than the traditional vertical steps to access the highest reaches. There are long distance views of Bangkok from the top of the Mount. After taking off your shoes, perambulate in a clockwise direction beginning with the frontal view of the Buddha. Offerings are commonly welcomed. There was a sales area with food and Buddhistic figurines available for purchase. The exterior presented large bells, and aesthetically pleasing plants and waterway. As you exit the temple at the lower level, you will see statuary in amongst beautiful flowers and plants of animals related to the Buddhistic history.

One of the best views around. It can be a bit exhausting to climb up the hill depending on the season. But its well worth the effort. The view over Bangkok is great and can only be matched by some expensive rooftop restaurants.
The Pleace full place. I heard this place for long time and .. khew that here have so many and very long long story about budda very rescpected feel when standing in this place .
get ready to climb. Up a lot of stairs to see bells (interesting) and a good view of Thailand from up high. Not on my to-do list again.

wonderful views of old Bangkok. a very beautiful Thai Temple in very nice grounds and the gold is sparkling... I used to live near here 30+ years ago and they have made this a very nice spot to see old Bangkok from.

One of the jewels of Bangkok. Primarily known for the Golden Mount. However, a visitor should not miss the dramatic ubosot, set on a spectactular tile ground covering with absolutely dramatic Sema stones and their Howdah housing. A hidden gem is the Ho Trai ( library), very near to the area which encompasses the Viharn and Ubosot.

Worth a visit. The climb is relatively easy and the view is very impressive at the top. The grounds are quite nice, especially during the walk up. Not much to see in the surrounding neighbourhood though.

Wat Saket is not Wat Phu Khao Tong.... These two temple share the same precinct but they are not the same (as the Thais would say: mai muan gan). Wat Phu Khao Tong, AKA the Temple of the Golden Mount, is the temple with the golden chedi that sits high (for Bangkok) above the city skyline. It is an excellent wat to visit and the view alone is worth climbing the ramp/steps to see. However, this review is more about Wat Saket which is the temple below WPKT. Wat Saket is an interesting temple in its own right and is far less frequented that WPKT-which makes it worht visiting for the peace and tranquility alone. Why go? Well, for the following reasons: the giant standing Buddha in the 'no fighting' pose is a beautiful sight and the building next door is a royally accredited ordination hall for monks (often open only to men as designated by the small statues ringing the temple showing where it is appropriate for men and women to be - but only on official occasions it would seem as my wife entered the temple without fuss). If you are into temples and their various roles within the country you're visiting then these two temples provide a nice contrast.

Great Views and Beautiful Grounds. The golden chedi on the man-made mountain (used to be the highest point of Bangkok until recently) is beautiful with great views - in the morning and also sunset. The temple grounds should also not be neglected particularly the beautiful old Scripture Library (http://www.flickr.com/photos/iprahin/6861670236/in/set-72157622548626235) and Prayer Hall. The surrounding streets are interesting too.

Unique and tranquil and very different from other temples. The Golden Mount is a unique, man-made small mountain with the temple on the very top. Winding stairways take you up around the sides of the mount, which is planted with varieties of lush jungle foliage, with waterfalls and ponds all around. The city noise seems to hush right up when you are climbing, and it left me feeling very relaxed. This is a very different experience from the other temples you might visit in Bangkok and I recommend it highly. You might also want to visit the nearby Wat Ratchanatdaram to complete the afternoon.

Wonderful temple, nice view from the hill, must see in Bangkok. This is a must in Bangkok, as you will have a nice view on the town. The entrance is free of charge. You can even go to the top of the temple.

A trip up the Klong to Wat Saket. Wat Saket, aka "The Temple of The Golden Mount," is off the beaten track in terms of easy access. Bangkok's conventional public transport systems, namely the skytrain or MRT, don't go anywhere near it. Most consign themselves to the drudgery of a long, hot taxi ride. However, there is a another less conventional way of getting there that the locals use everyday; the water taxis. Take the MRT to Petchaburi station. Get off and take exit number 2 and it's then a short walk to Klong Saen Saep jetty to catch a water taxi. The twenty minute ride involves a change of boats, at the mid point of the trip, but for fourteen Baht, full fare, it's a trouble free ride down the klong as you avoid the chaos, and traffic congestion, of Bangkoks roads. You alight at a jetty, from which you can actually see the Temple of the Golden Mount, and it's then an easy 5 minute walk to the entry gate. If you're feeling hungry, after the climb up to the Golden spire, you might want to try the Sorn Daeng restaurant down at Democracy Monument. It's one of Bangkok's best kept secrets when it comes to reasonably priced, but excellent, Thai cuisine. Get a map and It's an easy 10 - 15 minute walk from Wat Saket. Bon appetite.

Amazing City Views!. The Golden Mount is fantastic, going up the you are greeted by little Buddhist statues, bells and beautiful flowers. At the top there are amazing views all over the city, apparently sunset there is amazing but we were there 3 hours before sun down which is a shame. This is a must if you are sightseeing in Bangkok.

Interesting but random. We visited the Golden Mount on a whim. I didn't know what to expect. It was super crowded, and kind of random. The plus side is, it has a great view of downtown Bangkok, and on a hot day, there is a nice breeze going.
Wat Saket. Nice walck up to the monastery roof :) view of the city .Fortune tailor sticks in the corridor at the ground floor are available if you like to know your good or bad LucK :)
the view is the best thing about it. the mount itself is nice to climb. the 300 steps are easily done and then the view is great. The temple at the top is not really fantastic.
amazing city Panorama. Brilliant view of the city from the TOP of the GOLDEN MOUNT ....very near the JIM THOMPSOM HOUSE... good walk up to the GOLDEN MOUNT (many steps to climb)
Nice for one visit.. This is basically on the itinerary of the Bangkok first-time visitor. Bangkok is always fun and exciting.

Magnifient religious monument. Quite incredibly, this was my 1st visit here (in 12 years of visiting Bkk). I just didn't know it existed! I asked my tuktuk driver to 'take me to a big temple' & this is where I ended up. It is beautiful & impressive with a 360 view from the top. The spiral walk to the top was worth the leg ache & major water loss on a very hot, humid & thundery day. Bottled cold water is thankfully available at the top (as is a cool breeze on one side). Not for physically impaired visitors I would suggest. This was one of the key highlights of my visit.
Worth the Climb. This is a unique experience. Walking up the mount is really interesting and the view from the top is amazing. Quite a spiritual place.

Worth the hike up the hill. This is a Wat worth going off the beaten path for. There is a bit of a hike up, but the view is great, and the temple area is worth the trip. Don't be shy about ringing all the bells for good luck!
golden mount. we went from soi 4 and found it hard to get a taxi driver willing to take you there but no problem getting a tuk tuk back ,, it is well worth the visit and very intersting

Amazing. A beautiful temple with fantastic views. Well worth a visit but chioose your day carefully. I went on a Buddhist holiday which was lovely because I was able to see the temple as a place of worship rather than a tourist attraction but it was VERY crowded. Be aware there are some steep steps to get to the top...maybe not suitable for people with disabilities or who are less fit/active.

Gorgeous view. Contrary to what most locals will tell you, you can walk there from Khao San Road. It took me 15 mins walking with gusto. It's really peaceful and you get a great view of the Bangkok skyline.

Great view of city. This is a very interesting place to go to. There are a number of steps to get to the top, but the view of the city is beautiful from there. Loads of bells to ring on the way up (so typical of Thai wats). Interesting burial area at the base of the temple hill. This can easily be accessed by a klong boat from Siam.

Pleasant and relaxing. Everytime I am in Bangkok I like to see this place. It is quiet, there are no crowds and it gives you a peaceful and relaxing feeling. Nice, easy walk up to the top, views are not outstanding but still very pleasant.

Nice walk and view. Another wat in the city - worth to visit. At the mountain you get nice view of the city. We walked there from Khao San - it takes about 50 minutes. On the way you can see more Thai people and their common lives.
Nice view. I loved how the steps wondered/snaked gradually up to the Golden Mount....Ringing bells along the way ...it was a spiritual feeling. Worth a visit.

Great view of City. Taking stairs to the top, we reached the place. While climbing the stairs, it was little slippery as it was raining, but the views unfolding level after level were astonishing. There is a top most level which is connected by internal stairs and leads to the golden pagoda structure. From here you get the best 360 degree view of Bangkok. It is closed by evening, so not possible to get night view.

Worth going. Lovely temple on a little hill, from where you have a great view of Bangkok. Tip: Go there taking the canal boat from the canal next to 'Central World'. It's cheap and it's a great experience!

Free but not special. The best thing about Wat Saket is the price because it's zero baht, however that is probably because they would struggle to charge much as it isn't particular speci or spectacular, and the view which you have to make a trek for isn't even that great.

Temple with a view. You have to climb a hill to get to this temple hence the name. Include this in your list of temples to visit when you're in Bangkok as it provides a great view of the city once you get to the top.

A peaceful break. Contrary to what we thought it was not hard to get to the top, and along the way you have plenty of nice details: bells of all size, a big rgong you can ring (and make a wish for free ! ), mini waterfalls, flowers, waterlilies and nice views of Bangkok. The top terrace was hot but the golden bell is great. We loved it

An amazing view. The Golden Mount is incredible. Your journey starts at the bottom and as you make your way up the stairs you can ring the prayer bells. The view from the top is what most tourists come to see and it is worth it. But for the locals who are visiting and some tourists there is a very special reason to visit as this was supposedly the site in which relics of the Buddha have been kept. Wether they are still there or not who knows but a very special place in deed

Beautiful view. The view was really nice and it's not a high mountain at all. You can easily walk up the stairs and they decorated the pathway quite well. Plus, you can also walk to the attractions nearby and it's worth it! Don't believe those who tell you that the temple is closed. It's open all the time!
Good view of Bangkok. Good views of Bangkok and nice breeze once up high. It was quite quiet when we went so could have a relaxing walk up, taking photos etc without lots of other tourists.

Stands Out among the Rest. Solid gold against blue sky. Massive and plain against colorful and decorative pagodas. The simplicity and elegance of the Golden Mount in contrast to the extravagant structures surrounding it is what makes stand out among the rest. I personally believe it the most dominant structure in the Grand Palace complex.
Nice view of the Bangkok. Nice walk up and great view of the Bangkok city. Advantage is that it is for free. The temple on the top isn't so much interesting, but also worth to visit.
Nice view of Bangkok town. Golden mount is a small Buddha temple on a hilltop- good for an early morning visit (entry free) and gives nice view of the town. Do not miss
Average. If you have a lot of time in BKK, you can climb up the stairs and have a nice view over the city. the temple itself is disseapointing, so not really a must do...
ariel view of bk. it is very good place from where u get ariel view of bk nit is plesent also u get peace of mind from trafic of bk

golden temple. our tour guide did really well exoplain behind the reason to build this temple.all the temples are rich in the city and well maintained .do not shout and don't misbehave ,we saw some russian tourists dancing round the park which is not quiet cool
A view of Bangkok is hard to come by. Bangkok is a swamp and this is the only place that naturally offers a good view of Bangkok. Well worth the walk.

Quiet with great views. A quiet relaxing wat with great views and photo opportunities in the midst of the City. Well worth a visit for a tourist looking for a break or a resident looking for something a bit different.
one more temple in BKK. To be honest it was ntg special, yes its beautiful, but with so many gorgeous temples this is just one more...

Impressive. Quite an interesting landmark in Bangkok, it's one of the few things you can spot from more than a street away, which (skyscrapers and blocks of flats aside) is a rarity. If you go on the right days, then you can go in for free even as a farang, which makes it even better for those on a tight budget, like myself!Quite an interesting building, definitely worth a visit.The only downside is that it's perhaps not quite as amazing as the local Thai's made it out to be when giving directions to it!
Silent place in noisy Bangkok. I love this place as it seems to be always qiute and peacefull. When the city makes me crazy, I can have a quite moment here. Go and enjoy the happy life.

Don't miss this. This is my favourite temple in Bangkok. So peaceful and serene, with stunning views. If you only have a short time in Bangkok, don't miss this place. If you're a long term resident and you haven't been, take an afternoon off and go!

For Sure this is a place to see. Best views of the center of Bangkok, quite a few stairs, but a nice temple and upstairs facilities. It was free, but I think I was lucky that I picked on a holiday or something. Liked it. Recommend it!
A beautiful temple. Free admission, beautiful Buddahs, a mixture of tourists and the faithful, just be aware that it involves climbing a LOT of steps, so not for those how are not so fit!
The hieghest place in Bankong. Evey one who visit Bankong should see the golden Mount after visiting the Grand Palace
A "don't miss" site. This place is lovely and a great stroll. Go to the top and enjoy the views, too.

Religious Feelings can you get here. This was really the best religious attraction in Bangkok - nearly no tourists and just local people are here for a prayer. Forget the tourist attractions like the Wat Kreo, Poh and so on.Here you can enjoy not even a perfect view, you can even ring huge bells while going up and down (without strange guards at every gate). And while I'm writing here, this place doesn't cost you anything and gives you the most of buddism in Bangkok!
Beware, lots of stairs!. Maybe not the best thing to do when he sun is at it's hottest but definitely worth it. The views alone make this attraction a must. Don't forget to get your fortune :)
View was amazing. Long hot walk to the top but well worth the trouble.

Panoramic View of the Old City. Be prepared to climb a long flight of stairs when you visit Wat Saket. Upon reaching the temple, you will see a panoramic view of the Old City. The temple is not so grand, but you will see a humongous bell on the temple grounds, and the view itself is worth the long climb up.

Great view. Good breeze and great view. Ring the bells, rub the gong. Yes that is right... If you find the huge gong, you can actually rub it and get it to hum/vibrate like you would a wine glass. The shinny spot is shinny from all the rubbing. Nice area around the wat to see local industry and merchants

So cool!. We stumbled upon this by accident. Kinda got into a tuk tuk on the advice of a random local, and after many other stops he finally dropped us off here. There was a market that surrounded the outside, where you can get lots of cheap street food, this included bugs and grasshoppers for those who are more daring than I! The Golden mount is free to get into, but do leave a donation in one of the many boxes, as it's the right thing to do. You start your assent at the bottom and spiral your way to the top, ringing bells and hitting gongs on your way up! The views are amazing! I would recommend you visit here, as it's a great little temple with a difference and ringing each bell gives you luck and send your prayer out to the world!
What a Wat!. As with everything in Bangkok there are plenty of stairs. Great views from the top and plenty to learn about and read about. Can get a blessing from a Monk here. Great.

Great view. From the top of the Golden Mount, it was a great view. My daughters loved ringing ALL the bells all the way up. Apparently we hear that it's suppoed to bring good fortune. Very cool nonetheless.
Hidden Nice Place. The Saket temple is not so well known as the others in Bangkok and it is normally not so crowded! but it has a kind of charm and some nice views, as it is placed on top of a hill.

Steep climb but rewarding views. Very steep climb with lots of steps to the top of the Mount. But the views over Bangkok are rewarding and it is worth the climb. It is a short tuk tuk ride from the Grand Palace area but not as popular so much more enjoyable with less crowds
Tuk Tuk tour. Left the river boat and jumped on a tuk tuk and this was one of the areas we visited, it was very hot but well worth a visit, great views of Bangkok from the top.

A good way to view Bangkok. This is a worth a visit as it lets you see a totally different Wat as you climb it by walking around it. I heard it being called the Golden Mountain, and .thats what it really is. By climbing it you get to view a bit more of Bangkok from a different area.

Up to the Mountain of Gold. If you have a (regular) good constitution, you can hike up to the Golden Mount located in the middle of Bangkok. It isn't very strenuous and there are places to rest along the way. Altogether only about 10 minutes. The views of the surrounding temples, houses, and river will amaze you. Unforgettable.

Beautiful!!!. Visited the temple on the 4th day of my stay in Bangkok. Got to know about this beautiful temple while going through the travel book on Bangkok given by the hotel guys. Popularly known as Golden Mount, the name truly stand by its name. One needs to climb at least 100-150 stairs to reach main temple. But the journey (aka climbing the staircase) is surely worth the effort. The view it gives you is truly exceptional and magnificent. Happened to visit this temple in morning hours when there wasn't any rush so I could spend lot of time and enjoy the view, vicinity and spend some one-on-one time Buddha :D. Do ring the bells as you go up.
dirty. dirty road a lot of stray dogs. Smelly old houses around there.

Beuatiful and very few tourist. One of the lesser known attractions but definately worth a trip - get a Tuk tuk there. You walk up 500 steps to the temple at the top which gives great views over Bangkok. You can also ring huge Buddhist bells as you go up
nice. very nice place to visit but also, it's very high to climb. i left my mom at the foot of the mountain 'coz she can no longer go up. =( but it's an experience i can not miss.

Beautiful View of Bangkok City from Top of the Temple. we went to Golden Mount in our last day in Bangkok, using Saen Saep Canal from Saphan Hua Chang Pier (in the back our guesthouse - Wendy's House), just 15 minutes to Panfa Pier. We walk about 10 minutes to the temple and straight go up to maybe about hundred or more stairs. And yes its beautiful view from the top, love it very much.

Wonderful view, not much more. The golden mount would be low on the visit list I would make. The view from the top is great and you can see the whole city but other than that it is not worth the ride.

Fantastic views over the city. This is worth a trip simply to get a fantastic view over the city. The temple at the top is nothing special though. Take a bottle of water. It may not look very high, but on a scorching hot day, you'll need it!
A must-see for travelers to Bangkok. This is well worth the journey-the view from the top of the Golden Mount is amazing across Bangkok.
Can't miss. You can see the city view from the top of Wat Saket. Also blessed for good thinds to your life
Nice view. there are a few meters to climb around the wat, it's a good idea to bring some water along - you might need it...

Beautiful Temple. Worth the visit and climb the steps to the top of the mount - views are simply amazing. Can be hard going climbing the steps in the intense mid-day heat - closes at 17:30 free to get in.
Another wat, this one has a free entry. Another wat in the city of wats. We did enjoy our walk to the top, the steps were very easy to climb despite the heat. The view is OK but nothing special.

LOVE it, LOVE it, LOVE it!. After living in BKK for over a year, we have finally visited Wat Saket! Not only is it a great view, but it is a beautiful glimpse into culture, faith, and country. Shouldn't be missed!

A unique place in the city. This Golden Chedi is located on top of a man-made mount. It is quite an amazing sight in the middle of this huge metropolis. Steep stairs lead you up and down the Chedi platform. There is a different view of Bangkok from up there.

Disappointing view pleasant climb. We walked to Golden Mountain from Khao san road which only took about 20 mins. It was free for us to enter and the walk to the summit of the mountain, towards the temple was a spiral staircase surrounded by trees and the sound of monks humming. Once at the top you could see alot of Bangkok, sadly though this means skyscrapers etc. Considering its free its worth a trip but it would only fill an hour maximum.

Give this place a visit for the Vista.. I was told about this place a few years ago. It is a short walk from the Kao san road .Worth the walk. You get a good 360 degree look at BKK. fromm the only natural High point in the city. DO NOT miss this place!
Must have strong legs. After a long hot day, we were not able to climb to the top. Shame because it loomed beautiful.
Ok. From a particular angle, that being one of distance this temple looks great. It's nice once you get up there and have a look inside but the view of Bangkok is a bit disappointing.

Quite un-usual but quite stunning.. Save some energy for the walk to the top but the view is worth it. A beautiful place with a temple nearby and the famous Ghost Gate area nearby too. It is worth visiting this very historical area in the early evening or late afternoon so that you can eat Pad Thai at Ghost Gate for your supper after visiting the Mount and the temple too.

Check out what was once the highest point in Bangkok. This is the temple you can see on the two baht coin and it is certainly worth it to see it in person. However, you will have to climb up a bunch of stairs that wrap around this mini man-made mountain. There is no entrance fee as long as you don't climb up the final bit of stairs to the top viewing terrace, but, seeing as you climbed so far, you may as well just go to the top for such a small entrance fee. Once when I went there, there was nobody to take my money to climb onto the top part of the temple. I like this place because you there are not a lot of tourists. From this temple, you can go see Khoa Sarn Road or take a klong (canal) boat to Central World Plaza or another location in Bangkok. Just head out of the temple through a small gate that leads out onto a small road that is lined with shops selling wood, go over a small bridge (you will see the canal), and then go around to where you can see long boats parked. Pay your money and get ready for a stinky yet amazing ride. Keep asking the people around you where your desired location is and they will tell you. On the whole, I find the Thai people are very friendly and helpful to tourists who go off the beaten path. If you are heading to Central World Plaza, a reasonable walk to Pratunam clothes market (north) or to the BTS skytrain (south), the stop will be obvious because passengers will have to change to a larger boat to continue down the Klong (canal). The canal will take you all the way past the Mall Bangkapi to Happy Land. However, I suggest you do not go any farther than the Mall Bangkapi, a decent sized mall with nice places to eat and shop. There are even theatres and a small water park on the roof.

Wonderful spot. Spend an hour or two climbing Golden Mount for its panoramic view of Bangkok, or to savor the breeze which might mitigate the mid-day heat. But stop to look at the history, enormous gongs and tiny temples peppered throughout and you get a sense of Bangkok history unlike any other local destination. Had been to Bangkok several times before a friend advised me to give it a look - great tip to get a view of a gem in the middle of Bangkok.

Lots of temples...this is the best.... First day in Bangkok, we had temple overload. Without being disrespectful, once you have seen one, you have seen most of them- apart from Golden Mount (and Wat Pho). We rushed around in about 15 mins in order to see more temples, but wish we could have stayed here for a couple of hours. Basically its a haven right in the middle of the city, and by the time you walk to the top, you are rewarded with the best views of the city (better than the baiyoke sky hotel). It is lush and tranquil, and when we were there almost deserted. If going to BKK then this would be on my list.
great views. a bit of exercise but worth it to take time to see the culture and past of Bangkok, great views, I did this early and it gave me a feel for the lay of the land in Bangkok.

Tuk Tuk ride to The Golden Mount.. I could see this temple from my hotel window at the Grand China Princess Hotel. It was illuminated at night too. I decided on my last day in Bangkok to go there. I took a tuk tuk to the temple and then climed up the stairs to the top. There are amazing views of the city from this temple. The temple was not over populated with tourists and was worth the visit. There are many, many bells here too. If you get the chance, go there you will not be disappointed.
Not as popular with tourists but worth a visit. A good spot to learn more of the history of the city and the people of Bangkok. You need to go on your own as there are no guided tours.

Beautiful Views of Bangkok. A very nice walk to the top, lined with some interesting and exotic plants. The temple at the top is not as spectacular as some of the others but is very beautiful within its own right.

A Must See. Oy at Sourire Guest House suggested we walk to The Golden Mount. This was a surprisingly excellent experience. Climbing the 400+ stairs was easy as the stairs gradually ascend. There is a great view of Bangkok at the top of the temple. Buddhist monks were prominent. Bells and a gong are found along the descent stairs. The building itself is very beautiful. Cost is 20 B donation.

A golden mountain set in a sea of tranquility. I visited the Golden Mountain ( Wat Saket) in April 2012 and I was amazed at what I found there. The staff working there and the monks were both helpful and friendly. Round the base of the mount there are various visual displays and I found these interesting. The climb to the top of the mount is quite hard and I would suggest that an early or a later start is made to avoid the sometimes oppressive heat.The views from the top are fantastic and worth the long climb. There are refreshment and toilet facilities.
Somewhat of a hike up but great for the view from the top... A little out of the way and not as impressive as some other temples but unique and worth the walk up for the view of the city.

A landmark. This is one of the older temple with a long history. It has a great view from the top of the mountain. At the base, there's a new little museum displaying remains from what's left from Afghanisthan.
View. This Wat is a bit out of the way but the views of the city from the Mount are impressive and helps give you a perspective on the Old City.
Great view. As far as wats go, this has a great view of BKK. Especially good at nightfall.
Beautiful at sunset. The monks were very helpful! I went at closing but he made sure I went right to the top to watch the sunrise. Make sure you dress appropriately.
Worth every step of the long climb.. This is a beautiful temple and a must see. One can also get a great view of the old city of Bangkok from the top of the hill.

Great View of the City !. It takes a while to walk up the stairs but you can stop halfway for a refreshment in a small shop. The view is worth it as you can see all arounf the city (you can spot so may colourful temples amoungst the plain buildings!Also we met a local who told us to visit here - apparently if you hold pinkies with a partner while walking up, you will concieve a child together or if you hodl hands with a friend you will be life long friends... nice little idea to have.
Quieter temple than most, great view. Csn recommend this temple. Much quieter, peaceful and people go here to pray, hang well wishes and prayers on pray trees. Less tourists, and a great view.

Not the first options for foreign tourists. Not the best scenery of Bangkok you can view from high place (one of the best is from Wat Arun). There're many more for foreign tourist to visit before you consider this temple inclused in your schedule. More popular with local people since people come to pay a religious visit or gather for religous events/ local festivals
A wow. A big wow.. Wat Saket has features unlike any other Wat, including the crypts you pass on the way up and down, and the incredible views from the roof.
go see it. close 2 the Grand palce & emerald buddha go c this as well can see them all in 1 day
Good views. Better in the early morning. so Hot!! From the top, you can see the whole old town of Bangkok. Really nice views
Amazing View. Good climb and an amazing view at the end...many monks all around with big bells.

Great view easy to get too by water taxi along the canal.. Located at the end of the water taxi route this place allows for some of the best exotic views of Bangkok. It is easy to go into a tall building and look out a window but there is something much more satisfying climbing a hill with religious symbolism. To say the Golden mount is bright is an understatement you can't miss it if you are within 1km range of it. The neighborhood is equally interesting with many different craft streets. These are sois dedicated to various industries like door manufacturing and coffin making. If you are smart enough with a map poke around in the back alleys and get yourself a traditional prayer bowl. They have been making them for a very long time down there. These bowls are special because if they are made right they sing a note for a very long time.

Small temple to visit for an hour or so.. This is a well maintained small temple. There were plenty of other visitors, but it was not over-crowded. It is quite high, so involves walking up ramps & steps, but the view of the city is impressive. There is a small gift shop selling trinkets & drinks, but there are no pressures to buy.The worst thing about it was the taxi ride to get there, with the driver wanting to take us everywhere except where we wanted to go !!.

Worth a detour. Wat Saket is a real treasure. Most people are familiar with the Golden Mount, but they should not miss the rest of the monastery. There is a beautifully restored library (ho trai) which should not be missed, the Viharn has two very important Buddha images and the Ubosot is a classic example of early Rattanoksin art - murals, etc. The sema stones and their housing around the ubosot are some of the most beautiful in Thailand.

What a day. My son and I visited the golden Mount on a holy day and what a tremendous experience. We climbed to the summit with hundreds of locals who then prayed at the top. We also banged the bells on the way down. The views from the top over the city were incredible and the whole atmosphere was one of peace and goodwill. This place is still worth visiting on non holy days as the temple itself is stunning and the views amazing.

Worth the trip. Wat Saket is not on the 'easy access' tourist trail but if you want to see another side of Bangkok it is well worth the trip. Take the river taxi to Pier 13 and then either a tuk tuk or taxi. The climb to reach the top is quite steep and there are many steps in a one way system but once there you are rewarded with fabulous views over the city and a chance to see another stunning temple. The setting is peaceful and there are not the crowds usually found at the more popular sights like Wat Po.
Great views of Bangkok. wanted to see the sunrise from there but the top doesn't open 7:30 Very interesting, lovely views of Bangkok from the top. Go early not much shade there.

Go to the top to enjoy. The climb of the stairs to the top is nice, near a water way.
best way to go to jim thompson is to use the waterway

One for the Pilgrims. As Buddhism is not my religion, I only visited as a dumb tourist for something to while away and hour and get a view of the city. I understand it's one of the most important spots in the country but I can only report my expereince as a non believer. It was fine: nice walk through some foliage and up alot of nice red steps steps, nice views, nice monks, nice bells, nice gongs, nice people praying. I didn't feel so nice as I felt I was intruding and yet at all of these shrines, I'm always tolerated as is everyother tourist. If you're like me, it's worth a visit but not too gutting if you miss it. Minimal amenities onsite.
Love this place!. Nice little hike to the top and you get a fabulous panorama of the city. Arrive a couple hours before sunset to get a good ceremony in ;)
Go to Paradise. Visit here, Thai people believe that if you go to the top of the golden mount. It means you arrive at a paradise already.
a lot of local flavour. it's a bit of a hot walk up, but well worth it..great views on top...a lot of local flavour, for some reason it's not overrun by tourists like some other temples

Lucky us. We happened to visit on a Buddist holiday and arrived in time for sunset. It was lovely being part of the celebrations and the kids loved ringing the bells (OK, so did I)It's a special place to see the sun set on th city

A wonderful walk. The walk up the golden mound is beautiful, peaceful and almost meditative. The temple is nice and view from the top is great. The surround grounds where just beautiful and a really calm restful spot in a hectic city.

An amazing place. This is an artificial hill topped with a temple. Spectacular views over Bangkok and a fantastic atmosphere. You walk up an inclined pathway round the hill and pass various gongs and bells which you can strike. There are various Buddhas and shrines and at the summit is a stupa. The hill is wooded with flowers, small waterfalls and streams and quite an escape from the madness of Bangkok traffic.There is a nice and well-shaded cafe on the way up, and decent toilets.Depending of course where you are coming from, take the BTS to National Stadium then grab a taxi, or you can get there by water taxi from Pathumwan.

Climb!. We got there by tuk tuk. The mount itself is seen from every corner of the central part of the city. You need to climb the stairs for around 7 minutes and you' ll get to the lower level of the monastery. You can buy magnets and other staff there. Btw it is not really cheap. Also you can make a donation there. You can also climb higher to the roof. From there you can catch a perfect sight. All in all a really good place to visit.
Lots of stairs. There is a incredible view at the top but is about 500 stairs to get to the top. Make sure you want to go before start climbing.

Nice view. Came here while taking a 10B tuk tuk tour. Not really the best there is to see in Bangkok but if you climb it it rewards you with nice views of Bangkok. Don´t miss the carpenters in the street nearby.

Wonderful views. The climb to the top is well worth the effort -- the panoramic views are great. Take your time, and it's not bad. Many fewer tourists here than at the major temples. Be sure to ring the big gong three times for good luck!TIP: If it's hot and sunny, be sure to have a hat or some sort of parasol -- you'll be exposed to the sun most of the way up.

It was a long way up!. The heat made the climb quite tiring; but the views from the top and the bells and the atmosphere were excellent when we got there. It was not easy to see how you got to the very top- we had to walk round inside twice before we saw the stairs to the outside and the dome itself
Another must see. Takes about an hour but this is an interesting temple with a great view from the top.

Great 360degree View. The climb to the top of the temple was not too arduous & was well worth the effort as the 360degree views of Bangkok are spectacular. We spent a very pleasant 30mins wandering around the temple & taking in all of the artifacts.
Been many times. This is a great place to spend a few hours. Easy walk up, great view of the city skyline. Enjoy the whole grounds while you are there.

Breathtaking views of the city. I really enjoyed Wat Saket (the Golden Mount). It has amazing views as you climb up and especially if you go onto the roof (accessed from inside the room at the top).It is also free of charge to visit. The climb up takes a while and its worth bringing some water! On the way you can hear a monk talking about the Dhamma (Buddhist teachings) and you can bang some of the many bells en route. Fun! at the top is a sacred urn said to contain some of the relics of the Buddha. You will find a monk or two up there who will happily talk to you about the temple.

Climb the Golden Mount.. Walking distance from Koh San. Free to walk up and around, donation and shoes off to enter the temple on top. There are views the whole way up. Plenty of bells and even a gong that are interactive. Some good exercise walking up, easy to find landmark to meet up. INteresting neighborhood of woodcarving shops nearby. If you are in the area its a nice little excursion.

"Hidden" Jewel. Incredible views of Bangkok, unique design, and a chance to see an authentic Bangkok temple. It's huge and of course the Thais know it, but not a major tourist site, which only adds to the atmosphere. Best to visit on a nice day so you can enjoy the breeze and nice walk up listening to the sounds of the temple's bells and gongs.
Not to be missed. It's a cozy religious place, not to be missed. Well kept and beautiful, it gives peace of mind

The home of the Golden Mount, important, refreshing in itself.. I have been to Wat Saket many times since about 2002. It is one of my top 4 places to take visitors, along with Jim Thompson House (or the home of MR Kukrit Pramoj), a park (the exact park to be worked out with the visitor and depending on the time of the year) between 6 and 8 PM, and a ride on the Chao Phraya Express Boat (to somewhere that we agree on, usually including a stop at Thewet Pier to feed the fish). For the Grand Palace, etc. I put them on a tour bus and stay away (been there decades ago, done that). But for these four places I come back with them - partly selfishly for my own sake.Perhaps the stellar attraction for foreign visitors to Wat Saket is Golden Mount:http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g293916-d456261-Reviews-The_Golden_Mount_Wat_Saket-Bangkok.htmlcurrently rated #15 of 217 attractions in Bangkok. But a meander through Wat Saket itself is an opportunity to meditate. And a meander through the surrounding neighbourhood is also an opportunity to appreciate a neighbourhood. The surrounding neighbourhood is historic, but the modern-day activities (including many wood product shops) are worth wandering around (maybe with your camera).When you visit Bangkok, ask a Bangkok resident to tell you about the importance of Wat Saket, beyond the significance of the Golden Mount. It will give you insights into how a temple may be appreciated by people in Thailand, in addition to an understanding of the temple itself - as a center for learning and more.Here are a couple of videos of the temple:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JHGAP-H8ITkhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kfpvadw7vsoPlease note that this is not on the main tourist route, so (at least at present) does not push a commercial admission charge on visitors. Hopefully, this will give the visitor an opportunity to be more reflective, and less touristy, than at places like the Grand Palace.
Stairs are worth it. There are about 120 stairs to climb at this temple but it is worth it for the views that are at the top.

Lovely. Not a bad temple to visit, lovely view from the top. This happened to be my first one, living in Thailand, you start seeing one temple, and the next, it all becomes the same. Give this one a chance.
Impressive. Well worth the walk, very interesting and beautiful place. Has to be seen while you are in Bangkok.

Big Golden Stupe in the midlle of downtown. Really impressive, when we get there witha small boat from our hotel in approximatively 20 minutes and you see a total differnt landscape from Bangkok canals (klongs). This momument is a big golden Stupe (oriental tomb) builted up close to old city centre, on the way to go to Grand Palace area. This is lookings like Burmese temples and it a great location to move around to sightseething otehrs attractions. Again thsi is a don't miss place to watch.

Great vantage point, and a Wat that is actually used for prayer. This was a great place to visit, and it was very interesting to go to a Wat that is actually used by the local people for prayer. The wlak up is really not bad, and the 360 degree views are worth it. Make sure you find the actual top of the Wat, as it is a bit hidden inside the temple at the top. The Golden Spire on top is really beautiful on a sunny day.
Interesting. and the Pad Thai is around this corner not at Wat Traimit as I accidentally posted.

Steps, Views and a Gold-Leaf Plastered Chedi. The Golden Mount is more like a rocky, medium-sized hill, but semantic quibbles aside, this chedi-topped outcrop near the edge of older part of Bangkok makes for a reasonable destination for an afternoon walk. You will see the skyscrapers of modern Bangkok and the spires of the royal temples. You will not have this place to yourself, but it is much less of a tour-group-mobbed nightmare than some of Bangkok's historic wats. This is not the first place to add to your itinerary in Bangkok, but you won't regret it if you stop by either.

Definitely not my favorite Wat, nothing special. It's not that the climb up the hill is difficult (it's not, and to me it's at least half the fun of seeing a temple on a hill) it's just that the Wat itself isn't very special. You can see the big golden Chedi up close, which is nice (although the sun does hammer down on you while you're up there) but the indoor shrine is small, crowded and not particularly striking.However, it's not too far from Wat Sathap, and you should definitely visit that one.

Golden Mount. Wat Saket is located on a high point in Bangkok, Thailand. It is located east of the Grand Palace and can be reached by a walk, However some people might want to hire a tuk-tuk to get there. No matter, do not be deterred by people who tell you the wat is closed. Chances are that it will be open.

One of the more unique temples in BKK. After a while, all temples start to look alike--but Golden Mount is definitely unique. The best time to visit is during the Krathong Festival week in November--a huge night market encircles the temple at that time--offering an amazing variety of food. Beware of going at that time if you panic in crowds, though, because it will be packed with locals.

Beautiful temple with a great view. its worth the walk out but I wouldn't pay to get here... The temple is beautiful and very active with both worshippers and tourists. The experience generally consists of making a slow winding climb around the outside of the temple, past all these big bells and a couple of small sitting areas until you get to this indoor area which resembles an observation deck, complete with gift shop. Here benches surround open air windows, monks sit and chat or bless worshippers and tourists generally roam around gawking. Off in one small corner is a set of stairs which go up to an outdoor platform which circles the top of the Wat. Here are the best views of the city (if its not too hazy to see) so you'll probably want your camera. Not much else up there other than a set of those metal binoculars you put 10 baht into to have a up-close view of basically nothing. After your you may want to visit another nice Wat in the area. I believe its called Loha Phasit, its on the other side of the canal. Completely different and, somewhat unique architecture. The temple offers some interesting history and another slightly different great view.All in Wat Saket is well worth the visit but be sure to take the time to explore the area. Tip: There is a river bus below Wat Saket which will take you to either Chao Pharya River or north of the Siam Shopping area. Its tucked just under the bridge at the canal which separated Wat Saket from the main road. If you're looking for an inexpensive diversion, jump on and explore Bangkok from a different perspective!Cheers and happy travels!
Great views over Bangkok. The views over Bangkok from the top of the mount are very rewarding and make up for the climb up there (in the heat). Make sure to bring water and your camera.

Favourite site. Loved the Golden Mount. We went at sunset and it was really spectacular, seeing the whole city from the top of the mount and hearing the chanting from the temples below. Definately worth a visit.
Great view. The Golden Mound is a good viewpoint over Bangkok.
Wonderful spot. Great view. No entrance fee. Beautiful building. Get there via Khlong River Boats for fun.

125 steps but they are little ones!. Although it's called the golden mount, it's only the top part that is in gold. access is via a winding set of steps with temple bells set along the path all the way up. About half way up there's a rest station with coffee and toilets. When you get to the top there are several small shrines and figures, and the mountain itself of course, faced with tiny golden tiles. Most impressive. we spent an hour there, entranced.

Special on New Year's Eve. We visited the Golden Mount on New Year's Eve and at about 8pm walked together with thousands of Thai people with candles and offerings up to the temple. It was a very special and unforgettable experience. Some nice views from up there.
intersting and a nice view. Nice place to look at the city from an elevated view point. Interesting statue
Great view. This place is beautiful. Well worth the trip. The view from the top is great, even with the smog!

Great view. It is quite a walk all the way up and the terras can be pretty hot on a sunny day by the view over the city is spectacular. Also it is recommendable to read some thing on the Pu Kao Thong, ( golden mountain in THai) before climbing it as this makes thing more under stand able. In the old day very poor people who had died were here displayed for the falcons and vultures.
Nice!. A nice long climb to the top. This place is a must-see

Great temple once the highest point in old Bangkok. Wat Saket and the golden mount should be on everyones itinerary I think. definitely worth the effort to look out towards the river from what was once the highest point in Bangkok. If you get a chance to visit here around Loy Krathong in November so much the better. An unforgettable experience as thousands of families and coules float their krathongs along the canal just outside.

High above Bangkok. The temple is great, and so different from what you can see in different cultures. You get to walk up a flight of stairs, see a gigantic mound or bell like structure at the top, from where you can also view the whole of Bangkok, and then come down a different fligh of stais, and ring all the beels on the way down, in order for your prayers, which you have said at the top, to come true.

It's nice... but not much else. OK, if you're in the area and have nothing else to do, have a wander around. There are a lot of steps and not much to see or do.The best time to see it is when there's an event eg Loi Krathong or Songkran festivals. Then there are lots of Thais doing Buddhist things.Apart from that it's a bit over-rated.

Phu Khaw Tong. * The climb is not too taxing as you wind your way up and around a combination of half-steps and ramps.* The views are great as the temple towers above the rest of the city (given that BKK is so flat).* Often there are monks here who speak English and conversations with them can be very interesting.* A great way to see Thai people engaging in their customs and rituals (wat-ta-na-tum) as they pray and give offerings at various points of the temple.* Wat Saket nearby is also very interesting.
Just go for it.. A trip to the Top of the Golden Mount will take something of your breath. But finally at the Top you will have a fantastic view of Bangkok. So, Just go for it.
The watchtower. A nice way to see the city from a temple. But the temple itself is nothing special and not so touristy.
Lovely. Ignore the locals who says "it's closed today" and go anyway.Tricky to find but worth it. Lovely walk up and nice view. Too bad it closes before sunset to get nice aerial photos...

Great view of Bangkok. My favourite temple in Bangkok as it offers views and just being on a man made mountain is interesting as well. At tmes the golden stupa is covered in cloth to represent the holy season There are a lot of stairs and Bangkok is notoriously hot, but the view makes it worthwhile.
What a tranquil place. Lots of nice statues and tranquility. Has alot of stairs to climb but well worth the view of the city
Superb views and surroundings. It worths going because of its superb views over Bangkok.

Quiet but beware of smooth talking strangers. Nice and quiet. It was an easy climb to the top of the Golden Mount adjacent to the Wat Saket and along the way we could try banging a gong or two. At the Wat Saket, an overly friendly local turned out to be a smooth talking man with other motives such as to persuade us to invest in the gem store our tuktuk driver would take us to. Beware.

Stairs Galore. Having stumbled upon this in my walking around Bangkok, my main impresion was a lot of stairs. You never really get a full look at the extirior since all sides are wooded. It had some nice spots to view the city from the top and a small but beautiful interior shrine.
Nice View of the City from the top. I was glad I climbed up it. The areas had some interesting buildings and canals
Impressive. There are lots of stairs to climb here, but it's a cool experience.

My favorite temple. An oasis of quiet in the middle of old Bangkok. Great views from the top of the man made hill. The annual temple fair is totally unique. I've gone every time I'm in Bangkok during that time (usually early November). Been there at least 20 times in my life and still love it
brill views. Good views over the city and is a free attraction jst donations

Take the canal boat from near MBK. The view over bangkok is worth the climb.Take the canal boat from just under the bridge (about 400 metres from MBK) for 12 baht and get off at the last stop. The Golden Mountian is clearly visible and only 5 to 10 minutes walk over the bridge and to the left.
Very well worth the trip to see this Golden Mount.. Took me. While to find this. But once I did I was very impressed. Worth the time to find it and enjoy it.

Impressive site with great views. Be prepared you a big climb. You need to access the top by spirally circumnavigating the site. Its a big climb but well worth it when you make it to the top. There are plenty of other attractions in the area so you can certainly make a day of it.
Very nice temple with good views. This is in a lane full of local food and activities. Very lively with lots of crowd.

Great Gong on the path to the top. This site was not too impressive, quite dirty and with only a small temple at the top. Compared to the Shwedagon in Yangon, it was insignificant. One thing that was neat were the many bronze bells which one could ring while walking up to the site. Also, a great gong which had a fantastic resonance when struck made the trip to the site worthwhile. It may be a significant site in Bangkok, but I would consider it only a regional attraction.

A very funny experience!. You need to climb a hill to reach it but is is a nice walk if you enjoy walking in the nature. People with walking difficulties may prefer to use a wheel chair. It is pretty tiring.I bought some golden color sheets to attach to the buddha statue and when I was in front of the statue some girls pasted the golden sheets to me instead of pasting to the buddha.It was a funny experience!

Gorgeous Views. There is a festival in early November if you can coincide your visit. Festivities pick up in the late afternoon and continue through the night for Thai eats and carnival games.Mostly locals, this place is definitely worth tracking down and climbing to see a great view of old-city Bangkok. Bring your camera.

Perhaps my favourite temple area in BKK.. Golden Mount and its host Wat Saket are not hyped like some other sites in Bangkok. This brings several advantages to the visitor. The temple grounds of Wat Saket are not spectacular, but are very pleasant and more conducive to meditation than the touted tourist-packed temples. Golden Mount itself is an interesting, relatively young, archaeological site - you can see ruins of older structures scattered about the "mount" as you climb up to, and down from, the Chedi at the top. The views from the elevated platform surrounding the Chedi, and the meditative atmosphere, make this one of the more popular places that I take visitors to. The surrounding neighbourhood, filled with wood-working shops, is also interesting. The lack of scammers lurking around the entrances is also a relief (but common when you get away from the tourist-packed areas of Thailand).
nice BKK view. first you climb you'll be rewarded by the view, there are few budda statues
A Must See. This is a must see for travelers and nationals. It is a very popular place for everyone. Very interesting and words can't describe.

Wat Saket. The temple itself is not as impressive as others but the mountain and the way into the temple it's an experience...so peaceful, with little watterfalls and the sound of the bells...A moment of calm needed when you spend a day in bangkok! Plus very good views of the city.
Nice Views. It is a very long climb (steps) to the top. Great views though from the top of all of Bangkok. There is a shop at the top where you can get a drink or ice lolly after the long hot climb

Beautiful Waterfall and Awesome View. It's an easy climb, believe it or not, up wide stairs surrounded by waterfalls. Once you reach the top, the view is awesome. It's definitely worth the time to visit and enjoy.

Do visit for great views of the city. The golden mount/Wat Saket is the humbler cousin of Wat Pho and Wat Arun. Simply put , you just climb a lotta stairs to see a golden mount right at the top of the hill. The view of the city is great from the top though.
Do visit. if you're coming from Wat Pho take the no.47 bus
worth one visit. The Golden Mount is very interesting and worth at least one trip, it is a very steap climb, so anyone with a health problem may find it too much.

Golden Mount. The Temple seems just like any other but when you read up the history you appreciate it more. You get a good view of the Rama bridge from the top and a generally good eye over the whole of the city!

Great temple. Didn't know about this place, just it and followed a sign. Gives great views of the city as well as of the buddhists banging each gong as they ascend. A real gem and way less touristy than others.

WAT SAKET. You can take the Klong, or Canal boat, to the end of the line, heading towards Khao San road. Wat Saket is visible to your left. It's golden spire is quite impressive, It's free and a short walk to the top, for an nice view of Bangkok. There are not many Tourists there like Wat Phra Kaew or Wat Po which is inundated by Tourists and makes going there too uncomfortable, not to mention rude the Thai staff.

Wat Saket...something different. I thought it was just another temple in Bangkok....however for me...this was a bit special as it has a significant view from the top....stairs was not difficult to climb after all...and the bells ringing along the way...just make it special...It's worth a visit and a getaway from the busy Bangkok with nice view from on top of the Golden Mount...

Worth climbing the 320 steps for the view. This is a great place to visit to get lovely views of the old city, you can see Wat Arun, Wat Pho and The Grand Palace. We got a tuk tuk from Khao San Road and then when we came down we got a local line boat from Phan Fah boat stop to Phayathai (close to MBK). The Golden Mount has many bells and an odd gong or two you can ring on your trip up to the top. There is a cafe also if you need some refreshments. There is no charge to visit but there is a donation box at the top. You get lovely views from the top and there is a golden chedi, it is not a difficult climb and well worth the effort.

A good kick-off to Bangkok's temple crawl. Very peaceful temple that is a little out of the way but in reality only a 5 - 10 minute walk from Khao San rd. Good views from the top and the walk up is easy. Of course don't believe the tuk-tuk drivers who tell you the temple is not open.

A must visit, the views are spectacular and plenty of bells to ring. I was super impressed with the visit to The Golden Mount on my latest trip. There is something so peaceful about the Wat that makes you want to linger for a long time. Great views of the city from the top too!

Temple with a view. It takes some effort to go there as you have to climb a lot of stairs- on your way you have beautiful views of the lower temple grounds, buddha spas, plants, flowers and a lot of bells.getting to the top you can admire the view over Bangkok- the golden chedi and just reflect of how hard it will be to go down..I can assure you it is not as hard as the way up.There is no official entrance fee- but a donation is expected and you can not miss the box .It is worth the climb indeed:-)
